Consumer centric stocks are moving at high valuations, but in an election year, these are difficult to avoid, says Dhirendra Tiwari, head of research (HoR), Antique Broking. He is of the view that momentum should continue in 2019 as far as Indian equities are concerned. He spoke to ETNow. 


Edited excerpts:
Is that a happy feeling that we have managed to outperform the rest of the world stepping into 2019 or is it a scary feeling that we may just fall in line?

Exactly, it is a very happy feeling because not many times we see Indian markets outperforming for the whole of the year. It's good and not scary at all. 

Overall momentum remains pretty positive and therefore, there are events during this year which can be material on the market’s performance. Yet, we are pretty constructive and momentum should continue in the rest of 2019 also as far as Indian equities are concerned.



What is your big theme for 2019? What is it that you are advising clients to be on this year?

If you look at 2018, the big theme was consumption and exports. We had FMCG, staples doing pretty well. IT sector also performed very well. One can argue that the valuations sort of moved even ahead of earnings expectations. 

We have been contemplating for the last few quarters that probably the revival investment cycle will be the theme that is going to play out in 2019-20. The overall view is that while consumption remains a decent theme for the industry whether it is a good investment opportunity, one has to be cautious as valuations are trading significantly higher than the mean and averages. Recovery in investment cycle can lead to significant earnings growth in sectors dependent on the cyclical recovery and that becomes a very interesting area to look at for 2019.



Where do you find opportunities within consumption?

In consumption, retail for example remains a decent area of growth and valuation. If you look at staples, that has probably been trading at pretty high valuations. That is an area which is a market performer for us. In consumption, one would be a little more focussed on retail than staples. 

On the discretionary side, we are sort of cautious to negative on automobiles whereas we are positive on consumer discretionaries like air conditioners and consumer electricals and the like. There are certain opportunities in the consumer discretionary space, particularly retail, consumer electrical and electronics.



Where you would spot opportunities within investment-led themes? Do you think that the government’s increase in spending on infrastructure and engineering space would lead to a greater bias in buying stocks there?
I will just give you some background here. Look at the capex part of the country, which is GFCF, gross fixed capital formation. This has three components. One is private investment, the second is government and PSU investment and third is households. We have seen the government and PSU investment is shaping up pretty well for the last couple of years whereas private investment, which is almost 40 per cent of gross fixed capital formation, has been muted. 

What we are witnessing today is increase in utilisations. There has been a reasonable amount of growth in certain key sectors like cement, steel or you can talk about certain other areas of growth like ferrous, non-ferrous and automobiles and so on and so forth. 

As the RBI has pointed out, the system utilisation levels have also gone to almost 75 per cent, which in our opinion is a threshold capacity utilisation level. We are witnessing early signs of private capex recovery and this is sort of supported by all the companies that we meet. 

If that has to turn around, I would assume that there are a lot of opportunities in the investment recovery theme place. Corporate bank becomes a big large play within that space. We like capital goods and infrastructure stocks also within that category. These two areas along with select cement companies becomes quite interesting space to look at. 


Within cement, would you stick to sector leaders or would it be a more regional bet you are taking?

Cement has little confusing state of affairs in the sense that the overall environment remains quite conducive from the demand point of view. We have seen almost a double digit growth for the past few quarters and demand will continue to be strong because of the base effect. It can go to 7-8 per cent. 

Having said that, this has also attracted a lot of capacity expansion which in our opinion is likely to keep prices in check. In cement, it's very important to see the valuation comfort. We would pretty much go with the top company, which is UltraTech, and also look at some of the companies cheaper in valuations like ACC and Ambuja Cement. 



I was also just scanning some of your other bets and I see that there is a lot of focus on financing companies especially gold businesses. Muthoot Finance is part of your list. Are you going in for bargain hunting within financials outside the very obvious high quality names like Bajaj Finance, Bajaj Finserv in some of the beaten down names over the the last three months?

NBFC remains a concern area. The only area which has done pretty well both in terms of earnings and stock performance has been gold financing companies. That has been one of our preferred bets for quite some time. 

Muthoot Finance is one. It has been a big outperformer. We continue to have faith in that. As for rest of the non-banking finance companies, we think there may be opportunities in CV financing companies. That also remains an interesting bet. A few companies exposed to CV financing are the ones which we should look at. For the rest of it, we will have to wait for a while before we start looking at valuations and where the opportunity lies. 



Apart from the names and sectors you have talked about, have there been any large additions to your model portfolio or any changes thereof?

If you go to our previous reports and strategy, we had very significant overweight on consumer sectors, which are basically staples and automobiles. W have cut down meaningfully on these two. Consumer is now a market performer or you can say market weight and auto are slightly negative. These are key changes. 

The change has been on the positive side on industrials and infrastructure and also consumer discretionary. These are three areas where there has been an upward change. In the financial space, we continue to have a positive bias on private sector banks essentially.



What would be a big avoid for you from a valuation standpoint?

From the valuation point of view, there are two which have been the outperformers last year -- consumer and IT. If you look at all leading stocks in the consumer space whether it is Lever or Nestle or Britannia or the like, they are all trading at meaningfully higher valuation than their historical averages. That is point number one.

Second, the growth has been quite robust in the last 4-5 quarters. There can be some moderation in growth, going forward. Valuations are capturing the sustained growth that we have seen, which are largely driven by not only volume growth but also cost side benefits. If there is a moderation in growth even by 2-3 per cent, there will be some challenge to high valuations these companies are trading at. 

It is very risky to say a complete sell on this sector because this is an election year and therefore investors would like to remain protected within consumer names to some extent. To make money from these levels is quite challenging and therefore we recommend no fresh additions, hold on to these stocks. 

In the automobile space, there are weaknesses emerging on the volume and cost front. That is again an area where we think one should look cautious starting from the leader in the category.

Amit Khurana, head of equities, Dolat Capital Market, likes consumer largecaps and Britannia is one stock 
  
  where he is ready to allocate 5-8%. In this space, Marico is another stock he likes. Edited excerpts:

What is your base case expectation from the markets this year?
This year probably will be a tale of two halves. The first half is going to be quite challenging given the fact that we are getting into major global headwinds. We have the political season starting off in India which does not look as certain as was the case a few months back. India has outperformed the emerging markets over the last three-four months, significant premium versus historical averages, premium versus the emerging market basket. I guess it is going to be a little challenging to look out for returns in the first half in the least and then depending upon how the other news flow comes in, we will probably have a better picture for the second half but at this stage.

Our view is cautious to say the least because globally the picture is deteriorating. India continues to outperform on the back of valid reasons; crude oil has cooled off; currency has stabilised but how far this will take us in terms of outperformance and to what extent is a challenging question remains to be seen. There are going to be headwinds for India as well over the next few months and therefore we are a little on the cautious side. 


Given that Brent is still floating around $55 to a barrel, is there an opportunity in aviation or do you think the meaty part of the trade is over?
I have never been a fan of aviation as a sector. So my bias remains the same. There are challenges even in good times. The yields keep falling and competitive intensity takes over everything else. In bad times, when crude prices are higher, it becomes a cost pressure. So either ways, these models are not really able to make a sustained return on capital employed. India is one of the biggest aviation markets. I We should have been having an aviation sector which should be generating huge cash flows but that is not the case. So, my take is stay away. I am not a very great fan of these models.


It is often said US tech companies are correcting and it will have impact on Indian tech companies. This question will not be asked by institutional investors but some of our retail investors tend to connect the dots here. How would you respond to this?
That is a very valid way to look at it. We have also been debating internally for the last few weeks whether it really makes a material impact on the earnings for Indian IT vendors. I guess it is probably early for us to conclude anything but there could be some impact but that will probably play out in the second half FY20. 

As of now, we are holding on to our estimates for FY20. We had not made any significant revisions to that. 

But the other important part is Indian vendors do have strong balance sheets. They have strong operating bottles which have helped them to sustain in the last few downturns as well. To that extent, there is an opportunity for some of these vendors to reposition themselves. Valuations are not very demanding for Indian IT vendors. These guys are doing a share buyback which is deploying cash for the better and also helping accretion on the EPS front. I would not take a negative view right now on the Indian IT services. 

In fact, we believe that over the next few months this will be one of the safer places to have some allocation to the portfolio in specific stocks rather than go all out negative.


I am getting increasing consensus that one should revisit power utilities. Why do you think at a time when we are talking about economic recovery, cyclicals, industrials coming back, some of the smartest fund managers are saying buy NTPC, buy PFC, buy REC?
Part of the argument I would definitely agree to. The other part which we are more keen to push out for the sector is it is a defensive. The overall stability of earnings is far better and there is a preference amongst investors to move towards safer models and more predictable cash flows and the sector has not been doing much. 

The reason we are keen to look at that sector and within power, T&D is something that we have been bullish on and we still believe that there is enough opportunity to make money on. On the generation side, while the utilisation levels have marked up, it has not been strong enough for us to make a case to go out and buy. Our case is more as a defensive rather than as an outright buy. Therefore, we are probably on the same page but with a different perspective.


Which is one stock from the largecap space where you are happy to allocate 5-8% of your total portfolio?
We like consumer stocks. Consumer staples are richly valued but if there was one stock which I would still allocate, it will be Britannia. Another stock which will probably have better tailwind scenario is Marico. We have upgraded that and we like that as a name as well.

With oil price declining and hopefully with an interest rate cut and the fact that currency depreciation seems to 
  
  
  be over, foreign investors can turn buyers, Samir Arora, Founder and fund manager, Helios Capital, tells ET Now. Edited excerpts: 


Do you think from a market standpoint, the next 51 weeks will be good weeks or will they be choppy or volatile weeks?
Individual weeks could be choppy, but I do not think the overall collection of 51 weeks will be very bad for India. It has not been bad even so much in 2018 but in 2019 just because we do not normally have so many bad years in a row and even otherwise, should be okay. I feel good.


What is fuelling your optimism? Is it flow? Is it liquidity or earnings recovery?
It is a little bit of dealing with a lot of issues in 2018 and those no longer posing a challenge. First of all, let us look at the big picture. In any case, equity markets over the long term, do well. That is always a backdrop which pushes things at the rate of your earnings growth which is usually 14-15% but last year because of the currency depreciation and then the real estate/NBFC scare and also a midcap correction, the Indian markets did very badly in the initial part of the year. 

We can see for the last two-three months and with the oil price decline and hopefully with interest rate cut and the fact that currency depreciation seems to be over, there can be a situation where foreign investors are buyers and you can always justify that on the basis of current account deficit reduction and political uncertainty would be over in the next three-four months. Some earnings improvement in corporate banks can be justified but first we need an environment where people are willing to look at equity and not get weighed down by the fact that every day the currency depreciates. I am talking from a foreign investor point of view.


There is much talk about the heightened volatility that the election event may throw up. Do you believe that it is going to be really that choppy and a cliff-hanger for both politics as well as the markets? Or do you think it is going to be as always as history has told us that election years have given markets positive returns at max a two-day event?
It would have been a bigger event if in December, the results were not like this. Right now, you cannot build a scenario that BJP is definitely winning with a big margin and therefore there is no negative surprise that day. The markets will now discount it a little better and of course on that day, there will still be I think a 4-5% kind of move either way depending on who wins and loses. 

But unless the scenario throws out some very bad individuals as PM, it will be a one or two or a three-day event but it will still be worth 5% either way which is like a 10% difference but that is not a show stopper in markets where anyway markets are so volatility these days that you will not hold back your buying because it might fall 5% that day because it could also be a scenario that it goes up an additional 5-7% that day. But it is not a 20% up-down kind of a scenario which we had in 2009 and before that also in 2004.


Many are saying that this year would be really a year of two halves. Do you see it like that in the budget? Do you think, there would be a different portfolio strategy for first half versus what happens into elections?
No, I do not feel that way. What I could sense is that I think that if the US dollar depreciates a little because of they have one interest hike instead of two or something like that and then Indian rupee strengthens by 1% or 2%, it makes for a big cycle and logical difference to foreign investors. 

Foreign investors can handle normal equity markets which may be up or down but broadly there is a big selection of stocks to choose and you can choose what you want. So once the currency scare is out of the way which I think already is, I think foreign flows will turn positive. I feel you cannot have a runaway kind of rally which would mean something like say 20% before elections because that people will still like to negotiate but based on their other comfort factors and the fact, the election day or election week cannot bring you down more than 5-7%.

Whatever be the scenario, unless it is a super bad, low probability scenario of some lady leading a third front kind of a scenario, then you would not wait overly. So you will go along with a normal expectation that over a year you will make this much. I do not think it will be a big show stopper and you do not need to really change your stocks, you may keep some money in reserves if you want but that does not mean you will buy different kind of stocks. You will still buy the same that you always buy.


US markets have fallen and we are holding on. US markets fell more, nothing got affected because the view was that okay US economy will peak out, emerging markets like India will do well. A similar scenario played out for six-eight months in 2007 before the subprime crisis. US markets started coming down, emerging markets like India started moving up. Everyone said do not worry about US markets, we are decoupled. I get a same feeling right now that we are decoupled but after seven months, that decoupling got over and we got recoupled again.
We are not decoupled but please note that last year, the US market fell 6%. So do not get carried away that India did very well. The US market fell 6% in the total year and it fell out of that and 1.15% in December for whatever reason. But we also fell some 14% or 10-12% in September. So, I would not think it is decoupled. That is why I say that for making absolute money, you want the US market to do well or at least be stable. 

To outperform, you may do it if something very specific to US happens but normally US is the mother ship, you do not wish bad for the US market and think that we will do better. But I do not think US is in a 2008 kind of a situation. Please note that 2008 itself came after 70 years. It is not a normal bad year. In a normal bad year, you can do a little better or little worse but 2008 was like a global crisis. Even 2000 did not pose a problem not like that. So you cannot benchmark things of 2008.


Consumer stocks are expensive but it is not new. They were expensive in 2015, 16, 17 and 18 and yet if you bought an HUL or a Britannia or Marico, you made serious money. What is the way forward for consumer staples stocks? They are expensive but will they make money?
If you are talking only about these kind of stocks which are consumer staple, which are trading at say 45-50 times, you would have noticed that for the last seven-eight years, their stock appreciation has come more from re-rating of that earning rather than the earning. We do not buy these kind of stocks. We want a stock to be going up a little bit because you discovered it early and its rating has gone up on price earning multiples. 


Then, you want most of the stock returns to come from earnings growth and in all of these you will find that may be 60-70% has come from PE being higher but if you broadly define the consumer, we define it much more broadly. In consumers, if you leave out the HCV and commercial vehicles and all, you can do media, normal consumer durables and air conditioning companies. There are so many companies you can broadly define as ultimately consumer and not corporate or industry or even Titan. This is what you can call consumer. But if you say the consumer staples, we would not buy any of them.


In the market, this kind of portfolio churn or sector rotation is taking place. A lot of people are now saying that bet on the beaten down names like infrastructure and select autos as well which you just reiterated too. Do you believe that there is some serious money to be made in some of the beaten down names because you are going to see an earnings revival and sectoral churn is also going to be in their favour?
Everybody has some beaten up names in their own portfolios. So you do not need to look out for more because if you have 30-40 stocks, some will be beaten up. But actively seeking that as a strategy, I do not think it is so straight forward. You could also have a negative scenario of two kinds. One is that US has had basically a nine-year run and that is one of the longest in terms of their business cycle.

If they have a problem, the world has a problem and in India you could have a third front led by some lady from somewhere and that would be even worse. You cannot totally go one way or the other. We run a portfolio with about 35-40 names, of which some will be the largest names which are doing well and you feel comfortable that they would not blow you up in a bad scenario. 

There is no one strategy but if somebody wants to buy beaten up names, he is most welcome to. We are sure we already have some of them in our portfolio and so we are okay, but it is not a strategy. That way, if I buy one stock from this sector, that is not a strategy, it is a diversification. But I do not think it is a full blown case for buying beaten up stocks because some stocks right deserve to be beaten up, some have their lives changed with new changes in the world. There is no such strategy that anybody should have but you can buy a stock on this basis because you otherwise have some confidence that it will recover whatever it has lost and more.


Does Yes Bank becomes a case to look at at these levels?
Well, we are not supposed to discuss stocks but in a picture book sense, there are very few stocks which have so low hurdles to cross.


What about some of the infrastructure or select auto names which are getting thrashed?
We have Maruti, we do not have the others because it is still a dominant company and it has fallen a lot although we have had it for five-six years but otherwise we are mostly short some of the other auto two-wheeler types.


Let us talk about IT. The variable factor in 2018 was rupee. When we started the year, you said for the first time in my life I have gone short on IT. Given that rupee is now decisively trading below 70, what is in store for IT stocks?
After the very poor Infosys guidance in April of 2018, we did not have any IT. We sold out what we had thinking that again they are disappointing and the markets went up and all those stocks did very well. Today, I we own a very small weightage, in some general IT stocks. I would think I do not like it now because they have outperformed a lot They have got rerated on the basis of these macro factors. It is better to be domestically oriented where there might be an interest rate cut, where you can say capex cycle is recovering if at all a little bit here and there. But I do not like IT, we have a few stocks but much less than the index.


You have always maintained a ratio of long and short. So for 2019, if you have to look at your long-short positioning, are you likely to remain more long, less short or it is too early to get into that kind of a conversation?
There are two things; one is that as if you have a view for 2019 on the net, on the short side we maybe have a 30-day view. On the long side, we are always 100 long and short, depending on the individual stocks. Once in a while, on an event like when the introduction on long-term capital gains happened on that one day, the budget day, we might reduce it by 10-20%, but otherwise they are in the 60s range. We very rarely have more shorts than longs. Even today, we will be between 65 and 70% net long which means some 100 long and 35 short or 32 short and that depends on individual stocks, if we add or subtract. 

But we are not going to say that for this year we will be this much because shorting is more flexible in our minds than the longs. We want to hold for long, shorts depending on our view and our confidence.


A lot of parallels are also have been drawn between 2013 and 2108.In 2013, the rupee went down, crude went higher and there was a bit of a global concern because of taper tantrum. But after 2013, there was a big comeback in mid and smallcap stocks, and you ended up buying a lot of midcap stocks. One of the stocks where you made serious money was Eveready. Are you looking at hunting in some of the mid and smallcap stocks? 
No, we are not. But let me tell you that this 2013 connection you can also draw in 2008 and in 2011. The Indian currency depreciated between 10 and 15-17% in 2008 then the following years were very good because the currency did not depreciate it added to returns for everybody. 

So that way I agree, but in 2013 one reason was actually the political event which was a super positive and strong event of 2014 which basically led to that rally. That kind of an event does not exist right now. I do not think we are getting that big pop now. Also because the US market is more into the cycle, you will always feel that if not this year, the next year, US will have a recession and we may outperform. But we cannot have the kind of years that we had in 2014 where NAVs were up 70-80%. It is not going to happen. This is more a normal year.

Nilesh Shah, MD, Kotak AMC, is fairly positive about 2019. And he has solid reasons to back up. Macroeconomic scenario is looking better, he says. Shah also told ETNow that valuations are near their fair value. 

Edited excerpts:


Are we in for a good year, poor year or just a very decent year where we should not expect anything extraordinary?

There are many events this year which will determine the outcome. But at least at the beginning of 2019, we are looking at markets with much more hope than in 2018. Oil prices have corrected from $85 to $55-60 range, 10-year yield has moved down from 8.25 per cent to 7.5 per cent, the rupee has moved back from 74 to 69-70, banking liquidity from Rs 1,50,000 crore negative is now roughly about Rs 45,000-50,000 crore negative. FIIs who were sellers in September and October have turned out to be buyers in November and December. 

Inflation has been consistently below RBI’s forecast level. IIP numbers have started recovering. Overall, we are looking at 2019 on a macro basis with much more optimism than 2018. And more importantly, from the market point of view, in 2018 beginning, markets were trading at a premium to historical average, small caps were at 33 per cent premium, large caps were at 10 per cent premium, midcaps were at about 25 per cent premium. 

When I last looked at the number a few weeks ago, small caps were at 5 per cent discount, large caps were at 2 per cent premium and midcaps were at about 10 per cent premium. Effectively, valuations are near their fair value. Macroeconomic scenario is looking better and hence, we are looking at 2019 with more optimism than 2018.



What to your mind could be that big turning point for this year? Will it be earnings recovery or election verdict?

Definitely, market is actually looking at earnings recovery, but somewhere election verdict also plays a role in such recovery. Market is not discounting just this quarter’s or next quarter’s earnings. It is trying to discount earnings over next decade or 20 years. 

When the election verdict comes, obviously on the day of election results, it creates far more volatility. But later on, what policies are followed by the incoming government determines the trajectory of earnings. So, market will be looking at earnings recovery and post election what economic policies are followed by the government will have material impact on the trajectory of earnings recovery.


Do you believe that there could be a case where there is perhaps better alpha generation when it comes to small and midcaps. You were just talking about the fact that if you look at the large cap universe, that is still quoting at 2 per cent premium whereas small and midcaps are at a 5 per cent discount. So, could we see this realignment or readjustment in which small and midcaps give better value and returns this year?

Undoubtedly, we believe small and midcaps today from a valuation point of view is just a little below their historical average. But more importantly, from the regulation point of view today, the top 100 companies are largecaps, next 150 companies are midcaps and beyond 250 companies are all smallcaps. The sheer range of a number of stocks available in small caps are far more and hence, the fund manager who can pick those small cap stocks will be able to generate better alpha compared to slightly restrictive environment within large and midcaps. 


In that sort of environment, what are your top conviction plays for 2019? Against the backdrop of an impending election result, how would you spread out risks versus rewards?

There is one sector which we have started accumulating and we believe post election there could be a fair amount of outperformance over there. This sector is related to capital goods and infrastructure. 

Over the last four years, private capex has remained subdued for a variety of reasons. But now, capacity utilisation has started improving. From bottoming out at around 70 per cent, capacity utilisation across many industries is averaging 72-76 per cent. As this capacity utilisation starts improving, real interest rate starts coming down, credit becomes available and banking liquidity improves, we believe that private capex will revive. 

Along with government infrastructure development spending, we will see good days for capital goods. More importantly, over the last decade or so, many weaker capital goods players that had flourished during 2008 boom have started disappearing. Effectively, there are a few quality players left in capital goods and infrastructure segments. Their order book will become reasonably solid and they will be able to dictate their margin and pricing. 

Because of all this, we believe capital goods and infrastructure sector could be an outperformer in 2019 subject to the election scenario. The other segment which we are right now focussing on is related to rural consumption. The election-bound government will pump money into rural economy. Many state governments have announced farm loan waiver packages that will raise spending power of the rural economy. So, the rural consumption theme can be looked at the current level.



Real estate is considered to be the ugly duckling sector. But if I look at the headlines, RERA has come into place, disclosure norms are better, consolidation is the need of the hour. It is a sector which is not going to die down completely and it is a sector where GST rates are coming down. Right now, nobody wants to buy real estate stocks but after years and years of underperformance and with so many reforms which have taken place, is it time to be a buyer in if not all maybe 2-3 top names?

One limitation in the real estate sector is many of the leading developers of India are unlisted. For example, if we look at Mumbai, some of the top notch developers are Raheja, Rizvi, Lokhandwala, Hiranandani and so on and so forth. But unfortunately, none of them are listed on the stock market. 

If we look at some of the large industrial houses -- for example, Tatas -- which are foraying into real estate and will benefit from all the things you mentioned, again that is unlisted. When we are looking at the real estate sector, we do agree that this is one sector which can bottom out and there could be opportunity for investors. Unfortunately, when we look at the listed segment, the opportunities are very, very limited. 

We intend to play this cycle through other ancillary sectors such as cement, pipes, fittings, tiles and building materials companies. Even housing finance companies will be a better bet to play on the real estate sector and wait for listing of leaders that will give you a reasonable opportunity if they are priced correctly.


How do you think this long corporate bank trade will pan out for 2019 because that is the consensus trade? The view on Street is buy ICICI Bank, buy SBI and buy Axis Bank, some fund managers have told me that they own all three.

We believe this private and public sector corporate focussed banks will be a longer term trade. Of course, today it is becoming a consensus trade and to that extent there could be a risk, but if you look from a fundamental point of view, RBI in its report has mentioned that they expect NPAs to decline from 10.9 per cent to 10.4 per cent. 

This probably indicates that NPA cycle is now bottoming out, incremental lending has been relatively towards better credit. All those banks which had to provide for NPAs by virtue of their corporate lending should be coming out of that cycle and their retail franchise has been fantastic. 

All the three banks which you mentioned have fantastic retail franchise, their retail asset book is also doing well, the only thing which was kind of restricting their share price growth was the NPA cycle and if they come out of this NPA cycle, then to that extent those stocks could be outperformers in the market. Yes, it is a consensus trade, but many a time, consensus can prove correct also.


Is it time to diversify and extend your portfolio, have a little bit exposure to gold because gold prices have been holding steady ever since there was that whiff that the Fed rate pause is going to come in and that bet has weighed on the dollar. Typically as well, you have seen safer haven rush coming into gold, gold prices have recovered from the August lows. Is it time then to take that small maybe, 5-10 per cent kind of exposure into gold?

Undoubtedly, as of today, gold looks attractive. Normally, when Fed rate fund is rising, gold prices underperform. As Fed is indicating that they will not be increasing rates as quickly as market was factoring in a few months back, certainly this provides some sort of support to the gold prices. 

Second, from a currency point of view, if there is uncertainty related to election and that causes high volatility in the Indian rupee, then gold being dollar denominated could provide an alternative option. So at this point of time, I do recommend investors to consider gold as a part of portfolio. My only request will be please remember how much gold you own, you should not be too much overweight into gold.


While you outlined some of the sectors you like, I would want your overview on how you would be placing your bets on essentially the exporters or the rupee related themes because we have seen IT and pharma being top plays because of what the currency did in 2018. Do you think in a meaningful manner one should look at the export theme in the market, not just IT, pharma but largely extending out to businesses which draw a chunk of their revenue through overseas?

Undoubtedly, that is one theme which is a multi-year theme. Of course, IT and pharma are pretty well known export themes. However, there is an opportunity which is emerging for India and we have captured that in chemical industry due to US imposition of tariff on Chinese exports. Many of the manufacturers from China are moving out into various other countries. 

Some of the buyers of Chinese goods in the US are also looking to buy or diversify their sourcing base and that creates opportunity for Indian exporters. In the chemical industry over the last 4-5 years, Indian companies have grown at a rapid pace to fill the little bit of vacuum created by China. 

We believe that in quarters to come, China will keep on creating more and more space for Indian companies and it will be for Indian exporters, Indian companies to capture that opportunity. What we have done in the chemical industry will be replicated in textiles, garments into shoes and leather accessories. It could be into food processing and clothing.

There are many opportunities which are available because China will be moving out of export market and their American buyers will be looking to source those goods from other countries, including India. This we believe is Y2K equivalent opportunity of Indian IT sector for Indian manufacturing companies. 

All we have to look at is entrepreneurs like Narayana Murthy, Azim Premji, Shiv Nadar so that we can ride this trend for multi years. 


Where do you think some of these so-called hallowed stocks are headed -- Eicher, Page, Britannia I mean these were the stocks which have done wonderfully well in the last couple of years. PE expansion has been humongous, growth has been steady, the market concentration has been huge and a majority of the funds now either own Eicher or a Page, some own both. There are a very few funds which do not own none of these so-called four and five digit hallowed stocks?

From here onwards, to expect more expensive valuation stocks to get rerated further will be very difficult. It will be purely their earnings growth which will determine how these valuations can be sustained. 

And we believe from here onwards, at least in the expensive stocks, it is all about stock specific. If you believe these companies will be able to generate higher earnings growth, there will not be material return from these stocks over the next 12-18 months. 

This is not to deny that these companies are excellent companies, they have excellent business models, it is just that their prices seems to have run up a little bit ahead of what kind of earnings growth these companies are going to deliver. So we are pretty cautious in the more expensive bucket of stocks. 

We are taking all those companies on a case by case basis and where we believe that in our opinion, earnings growth will be higher than what is priced by the market. We do not mind holding on to those companies.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were trading in the negative zone with the Nifty FMCG index down 0.09 per cent at 30,254.60 around 11:12 am on Tuesday.

Shares of Godrej Consumer Products (down 1.69 per cent), Britannia Industries (down 0.54 per cent), Hindustan Unilever (down 0.41 per cent) and ColgatePalmolive (India) (down 0.24 per cent) were the top losers in the index. 

Tata Global Beverages (down 0.21 per cent), Dabur India (down 0.15 per cent) and United Spirits (down 0.06 per cent) too were trading in the red. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 10.40 points at 10,761.40 while the BSE Sensex was up 0.89 points at 35,851.05.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 19 were trading in the green, while 31 were in the red. 

Shares of Ashok Leyland, YES Bank, Tata Motors, ICICI Bank, Bandhan Bank, Sun Pharma, Hindalco Industries, Bank of Baroda, Vedanta, Indiabulls Housing Finance, SBI, Axis Bank, Infosys, BHEL and Bharti Infratel were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were trading on a mixed note in Thursday afternoon trading session.

Shares of ColgatePalmolive (India) (up 1.01 per cent), Marico (up 0.78 per cent), Godrej Industries (up 0.71 per cent) and Procter & Gamble Hygiene & Healthcare (up 0.63 per cent) were the top gainers in the index. 

United Spirits (down 1.46 per cent), United Breweries (down 0.60 per cent), Britannia Industries (down 0.45 per cent) and Dabur India (down 0.33 per cent) were the top losers in the index. 

The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.10 per cent down at 30,546.60 around 12:28 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 39.75 points at 10,815.40 while the BSE Sensex was down 113.66 points at 36,099.25.

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 19 were trading in the green, while 30 were in the red. 

Shares of Ashok Leyland, YES Bank, Tata Motors, SBI, ICICI Bank, Axis Bank, ITC, NTPC, Vodafone Idea, Vedanta, Indian Oil Corp, Hindalco Industries, Tata Steel, Infosys and SAIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: FMCG heavyweight Hindustan Unilever will release its December quarter earnings on Thursday, and investors will be keenly looking out for comments on volume growth and consumer demand environment.

Since rural growth of key FMCG segments, including detergents, toilet soaps, hair oils, shampoos, fairness creams and toothpaste witnessed an uptick last year, company's pace of rural recovery will also be a major point of focus.

Similarly, the market will monitor the performance of Lever Ayush and oral care. 

HUL had beaten Street estimates in its second quarter earnings by reporting a 19 per cent jump in profit after tax (PAT). Brokerages are now expecting it to maintain its growth trajectory for this quarter as well.

“HUL may maintain three years’ average volume growth trajectory of earlier quarters," said brokerage Edelweiss Securities.

The brokerage expects revenue, EBITDA and PAT to grow nearly 9 per cent, 18 per cent and 4 per cent, respectively, on a year-on-year (YoY) basis. "We expect HUL to record nearly 6-7 per cent volume growth on a high base of 11 per cent growth, the brokerage said.

The tax rate of 30 per cent for the quarter compared to about 21 per cent in the base quarter may keep profit subdued.

Brokerage Motilal Oswal Securities expects similar numbers for HUL for December quarter. 

It expects HUL's revenue to grow 10 per cent, with underlying domestic volume growth of 6 per cent in third quarter, while operating margin may expand by 150 basis points to 21.1 per cent, leading to EBITDA growth of 18.4 per cent.

"Adjusted PAT is likely to grow 17.8 per cent to Rs 1,410 crore," the brokerage said.

As per Kotak Institutional Equities, HUL's adjusted PAT may rise 2.7 per cent sequentially and 30.4 per cent yearly.

The brokerage estimates EBITDA to jump 28.3 per cent YoY and 6.7 per cent QoQ.

FMCG firms have a tailwind in terms of soft crude oil prices. Prices of most crude linked derivatives have eased sequentially and the benefit of it is expected to reflect from the fourth quarter. 

Brokerages are positive on volume growth of consumer goods companies. 

"We expect volume growth of consumer goods companies to sustain on account of farm loan waivers, MSP hikes, increasing direct distribution, muted growth of Patanjali, etc. Upcoming general and state elections will further boost consumption," Edelweiss Securities said.

NEW DELHI: The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.51 per cent down at 30,853.05 in Wednesday's session with most of its components trading in the red.

Shares of United Spirits (down 0.97 per cent), Hindustan Unilever (down 0.93 per cent), Emami (down 0.74 per cent)and Dabur India (down 0.73 per cent) were the worst performers in the index. 

Britannia Industries (down 0.72 per cent), Jubilant Foodworks (down 0.71 per cent)and ITC (down 0.61 per cent) too were trading lower. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was up 25.50 points at 10,912.30 while the BSE Sensex was up 79.51 points at 36,397.84 around 11:59 am. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 26 were trading in the green, while 24 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, Zee Ent., ICICI Bank, Tata Motors, Vedanta , SBI, Ashok Leyland, Bank of Baroda, Wipro, SAIL, Infosys, Bharti Airtel, Axis Bank and Hindalco Inds. were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

The Nifty FMCG Index has gained one percent so far in 2019 after rising nearly 12 per cent last year. The 15 member index trades at nearly 40 times its one year forward earnings which is also the 5-year average. It is still 7 per cent below the lifetime high level of 33,167 and analysts do not expect it to reach 33,610 in the coming one year. That implies a 9 per cent return. 

Here’s a list of high price-to-earnings stocks and where do analysts see them one year from now. 


Hindustan UnileverTrades at 52-times expected FY20 earnings, which is above the 5-year average of 44 times. The stock is 4 percent below the lifetime high and analysts expect a 5 percent return for investors in the next one year. 


Asian PaintsTrades at 50-times expected FY20 earnings, which is close to the 5-year average of 51 times. The stock is down nearly 6 percent from the 52-week high and analysts expect the stock to decline 4 percent over one year. 


Nestle IndiaTrades at 56-times expected FY20 earnings, which is below the 5 year average of 64-times. The stock is 3.5 percent below the 52-week high and analysts expect it to remain flat during the next 1 year. 


Avenue SupermartsTrades at 68-times expected FY20 earnings. The stock is down 18 percent from lifetime high of 1698.7 per share and analysts expect it to remain flat over the next one year. 


Britannia IndustriesTrades at 54-times expected FY20 earnings, which is above the 5-year average of 42-times. The stock is 8 percent below the lifetime high and analysts expect the stock to decline a little over one percent in the next one year.

NEW DELHI: Domestic equity market is likely to open flat on Wednesday tracking Nifty futures on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX Nifty)and mixed Asian cues. 

At 8:35 am the SGX Nifty was 10 points or 0.09 per cent up at 10,933.

NEW DELHI: Reliance Industries will report its December quarter results on Thursday. Analysts see a flattish profit and some pressure on refining margins on a sequential basis. Telecom and retail segments may show strong results.

Petchem margin, update on Jio business and capex-related plans will be the key monitorables, they said.

Brokerage Edelweiss Securities expects the oil-to-telecom major to report a 3 per cent sequential drop in consolidated Ebitda, but sees PAT to rise 2 per cent due to higher other income and lower interest costs.

“Weaker refining earnings (down 18 per cent QoQ) and flat petchem (up 1 per cent QoQ) will offset higher retail (up 9 per cent QoQ) and telecom (up 7 per cent QoQ) earnings. GRM is estimated to fall 7 per cent QoQ to $8.8 a barrel,” Edelweiss said in a note.

Motilal Oswal Securities expects the Mukesh Ambani-led company to report consolidated profit after tax of Rs 9,540 crore, up 1 per cent YoY and almost same as in the September quarter.

It expects the company to report GRM of $7.5 a barrel, against $9.5 per barrel in September quarter and $11.6 a barrel in the year-ago quarter. This would still imply a premium of $3.2 a barrel over Singapore GRM.

“Petrochemical segment is expected to do better due to healthy deltas and strong volume growth in the segment. We expect RIL to report consolidated Ebitda Rs 20,280 crore, up 15 per cent YoY, down 4 per cent QoQ,” the brokerage said.

Prabhudas Lilladher expects a 3.1 per cent fall in adjusted profit due to weak refining earnings, despite petrochemicals earnings and rupee (depreciation) tailwind.

ET Intelligence Group: When everything is right in the business, it is the valuation that’s the worry.

On Thursday, Hindustan Unilever is forecast to post double-digit growth in revenue (to over Rs 9,300 crore) for the December quarter, with no major deviation expected. Volume growth is expected to be in the range of 6-10 per cent on a high base.

However, it is the valuation that is of topmost concern to the Street with regards to the FMCG bellwether at this point in time.

The company is expected to post 12-13.5 per cent increase in revenue and an EBITDA margin of around 21 per cent. Investors will punish the stock in case of any negative deviation from the expectation — but they won’t cheer as much if HUL delivers on the expected lines.



The HUL stock is trading at 67.5 times its earnings per share for the past four quarters. The price-to-earnings multiple of the ET FMCG Index is 48.5. The HUL stock's five-year peak PE is 72.5 (hit in July 2018). The stock has gained 28 per cent in the past one year, hitting a record high of Rs 1,870 last month. Against this, the ET FMCG Index posted a gain of 15 per cent.

According to data from Bloomberg, 20 of the 39 (51 per cent) analysts tracking HUL have a ‘buy’ recommendation on the stock. Six months ago, 28 of the 46 (61 per cent) analysts had a ‘buy’ rating. The stretched valuation seems to have factored in the secular growth in consumer demand, limiting the room for a major upside.
