Besides the prospects of rural versus urban demand and input cost inflation, investors would be keen to know the management’s plan to integrate the proposed acquisition of GSK Consumer Healthcare, the company’s response to the fine slapped by the GST antiprofiteering body and the impact of increased government spending ahead of the general elections on consumer sentiment.

The confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in the agri input side and we prefer 
  
  
  agrochemicals over other inputs, Ravi Dharamshi, CIO, ValueQuest, tells Nikunj Dalmia of ET Now in an exclusive interview. There are good set of companies where significant returns can be made over the next two-three year period, says Dharamshi. Edited excerpts:


Well begun is half done or is this just beginners’ luck in 2019?
No. First of all, our tribute to John Bogle. There is a lot of contribution to the fund management industry and one has to recognise that. Coming back to 2019, we really went through a rough period in 2018, especially if you are somebody managing a midcap concentrated strategy focussed on Indian midcaps and smallcaps. 

Valuations are now in our favour and some of the things that were really bothering like crude or the interest rates going higher, have now fallen in place. We can be a little more sanguine about the prospects of interest rate hardening as well as the crude going up. That bodes well for the Indian midcaps and they are relatively more reasonably valued today. So 2019 will definitely augur well, much better than 2018. 


We had a global scare in the last leg of 2018. There was a scary selloff in Dow, a huge meltdown in the hallowed FAANG stocks. So far, we have managed to survive the first storm. But if this is a recurring or long unwinding, emerging markets like India will also get hit hard.
It is surprising definitely but I would say 2019 is going to be more a year of mean reversion than anything else. Since the 2009 bottom, American markets have had a huge outperformance to the world market. The global market cap moved from $25 trillion to $85 trillion over a span of a decade and the biggest contributor to that was from the US market.

Relatively speaking, emerging markets have underperformed significantly and this gap between developed market and emerging markets had reached a high point sometime last year and that I think is reversing. So that is one of the reason why we did not see a selloff even though nearly a trillion dollars were wiped off just from the FAANG stocks in the US. Since FIIs have been sellers in our market over last two years, it is not a phenomenon of last three or six months.

We are constantly being going down in weightage. Our market cap probably peaked at around 2.5 trillion and came down to 1.8 trillion. We have also seen quite a bit of wealth erosion and that is why today I am much less worried about global crisis setting off or some kind of contagion which can make our markets collapse. I do not think we are facing that kind of scenario today.


In markets we have to look forward but I will look back for last two years. 2017 was the big year for fund managers and smallcap investors. 80% of the market went higher. In 2018, 18% of the market either went lower or remains stable. What is in store for 2019?
You are right. One of our studies showed that in 2018, more than 50% of the stocks fell more than 50%. In that kind of a scenario, your portfolio cannot be too much different. But enter 2019 and there are many opportunities to invest and those risks where there are unreasonable valuations or unreasonable expectations those have been taken out of the market. Now there are good set of companies where significant returns can be made over the next two-three year period. It might not be immediately in 2019 because some of the concerns are real. The stocks have not come off without a reason. There are good reasons. But that is where the opportunity lies. But opportunity is dressed in overalls and looks like hard work. 


Are you able to find enough businesses which can give a potential earnings growth of 20% to 25% for next two or three years? Are those businesses available at reasonable levels now?
There is an opportunity in the market today in the kind of buckets that we have. What we look for is good business, reasonable valuation and a business tailwind. Now it is very difficult to find a combination of all these three things. So it is definitely very miniscule. But at the same time, if you were to take in a little bit of a cyclical headwind in the business or there are some with structural headwind, then there is a bucket of and a pool of companies available where you can make good money if you stretch your horizon into three and five years of investment. But you will have to live through next 12 months when the problems will still be in the transition phase of turning around. 

For example, PSU banks or real estate developers are going through some real tough times. Those are structural issues. But valuations are not an issue over there. It is only an issue of whether and if the sentiment will revive. If the sentiment revives, the business tailwinds will come back. There is a going to be a big supply crunch for sure. The number of players are going to be whittled down dramatically in real estate. So that is a positive.


Do you own a real estate stock?
No, I do not own any and only thing I am saying is that that is a bucket which requires more than five years’ horizon. If you look at something that has more cyclical business headwinds, then over there, your horizon can be three to five years and you can still make good money. Managing public funds, sometimes we face challenges of having a 10-year horizon. So, we have to look at three to five years. I would be more willing to buy a company which has some cyclical headwind going on and which can be corrected by say the raw material prices coming down or some amount of stimulus being given to the economy. Those kind of situations provide more clear and present opportunity for us today.



So if we talk about your portfolio positioning in Jan 2018 versus January 2019, how many stocks have vanished, how many stocks have entered and in terms of an aggregate approach is there anything new and different or is it an extension of the same?
The last time we spoke, there were stocks priced to perfection and especially some of them were on the consumption side. Now, we are out of stocks that are priced to perfection with a business tailwind. Everything is going in favour but there is no room for error. High quality, high performance, highly valued. The money has been chasing very few ideas in this market and those few ideas have become really outpriced now. As long as the business tailwind continues, the valuations can sustain but I think there is a real risk of a significant underperformance with a three-year point of view.


We have seen that in Eicher, we have started seeing that in a Page. , I think you are referring to the same obvious stocks?
Yes that is the pool of companies that I am referring to, no one particular name but that is the kind of thing. Whether it is Page or Eicher or even Britannia or VIP.


Raamdeo Agrawal told me one thing which is that mehanga roye ek baar sasta roye bar-bar, we are always trying to find something very cheap but it does not work?
No, no, we are not going down the junk road but at the same time Infosys can have 10 years of underperformance, Hindustan Unilever can have 10 years of underperformance. So, you better be clear about what you are buying and I think the risks are real in terms of underperformance over the next three to five years. Any long-term investors’ horizon is also a risk.


You have been bullish on private sector banks, select chemical names and select retail/fashion names. Have those themes extended themselves for 2019?
 In private sector banks, definitely the theme continues but probably now some of the larger or the retail banks are not the ones to be focussed on. Corporate banks are better placed and that is where a surprise possibility is there in terms or earnings as well as a comfort in valuation. 

Larger private corporate banks or even smaller private regional banks provide a very good risk to reward with a five-year point of view if the capex cycle was to revive and that should revive sometimes within next six and 18 months. That is a fertile area to look at.


You do not think corporate banks are becoming a consensus trade? 
Consensus or not, you have to look at how much of the ownership is with the institutions and if you believe that price performance has been fantastic, then the performance has not even started ye. Honestly speaking, they are still available. These banks are doing sub 1% ROA. Over the next three to four years, the ROAs will move from 0.7-0.8 to 1.2-1.3 and with some bit of leverage, the ROEs can move beyond 15%. 

In that kind of a scenario where all these banks that are quoting between 1 and 2 can quote anywhere between 2 and 3. We are at the beginning of the story, we should not be worried about consensus at this point of time. It is a large pool, FIIs have been selling and I do not see us being in an overcrowded trade by any stretch of imagination.


You have this reputation of being the pharma expert on the stock market. When you see an experience like Sun Pharma in 2018, it just shakes you that corporate governance issues have been raises at this bluest of the blue chip company, Debt is not a problem for pharma though growth may be challenging. What does that speak for the sector?
This does not speak for the sector per se, it is a company specific issue. The sector issues were definitely more on the FDA front and those are behind us. The corporate governance issues were not completely unknown to the market. It is only that they are out in the public domain today and they probably did not matter when you were a small company but today when you have trillions of rupees of market cap, they matter a lot more because all the global FIIs have taken an exposure to your stock. There is no choice but to get your act together, clean up the books. 

And you are right, they do not have net debt but that cash in US and the debt in India are not matching. They will have to probably get out of this mess in some way but it reflects more on the company.


We started with John Bogel but let us go back to our favourite investor Warren Buffett. We love to quote him. I wonder if he has to start charging IPs for his quotes...
Yes he should charge a royalty.


 ...he will be a richer man by a billion dollars at least.
For sure.


He pretty much is alluding to what you referred to that you have to buy good businesses when there is a temporary slowdown or news is bad. Where else do you see this kind of a thesis getting played out?
So one space where three-four years of bad period is coming to an end I believe is agri inputs side. Agri has been in a distress and it is more because of agri prices being down than anything else. The global cycle also was on a slowdown since the last three years and over here there is a very good possibility that over the next one to two years there will be a pickup.


Despite what data we are getting from rural India?
No, because there is so much distress that is when governments will be forced to take action and when government take action it will have impact You want to be positioned for it today.


Focus on where the buck is going to move?
Correct. Because there is distress today there is no choice but the agri prices to move up over the next 12 to 18 months and finally this is a cycle. If a farmer is not getting good realisation for his crop he will move to another crop that gives him better realisation and that will eventually create shortage in the other crop and that will make the prices move up. 

Cyclically, from agri prices point of view we are close to a bottom and we should move up in the next 12 to 24 months and that is the local cycle but even globally also, the commentary or the large chemical companies has now started being positive and they have started witnessing growth which had come down to close to zero, now they are talking about 5-7% kind of growth. 

So the confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in the agri input side and we prefer agrochemicals over other inputs.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were trading lower in Friday's afternoon trading session.

Shares of ColgatePalmolive (India) (down 1.15 per cent), Tata Global Beverages (down 1.05 per cent), United Spirits (down 1.02 per cent) and Godrej Industries (down 1 per cent) were trading with losses. 

ITC (down 0.85 per cent), Britannia Industries (down 0.84 per cent) and Emami (down 0.81 per cent) too were among the top losers. 

The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.58 per cent down at 30,559.15 around 12:00 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 19.25 points at 10,885.95 while the BSE Sensex was down 66.99 points at 36,307.09. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 22 were trading in the green, while 28 were in the red. 

Shares of Sun Pharma, YES Bank, RIL, Bharti Airtel, ITC, ICICI Bank, Ashok Leyland, BHEL, Wipro, Vedanta , SBI, SAIL, Indian Oil Corp and Axis Bank were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

The elections matter a lot to a speculator. For us, it is a question of offering an opportunity to enter or exit, says Ravi Dharamshi, CIO, ValueQuest, told ETNow's Nikunj Dalmia. Edited excerpts: 



Well begun is half done, or this is just the beginner's luck.

No, I think first of all our tribute to John Bogle. His contribution to the fund management industry is a lot and one has to recognise that. 

Coming back to 2019, we really went through a rough period in 2018, especially if you are somebody managing a midcap concentrated strategy focussed on Indian midcaps and smallcaps. Valuations are now in your favour. 

Some of the things that were really bothering like crude and the interest rates going higher have now fallen into place. We can be a little more sanguine about the prospects of interest rate hardening as well as crude going up. That augurs well for Indian midcaps and they are way better valued today and way more reasonable. 2019 will definitely augur well, much better than 2018. 

In 2018, especially the late leg of 2018, we saw a global scare and it was a scary selloff in Dow, a huge meltdown in some of the so-called hallowed stocks, the FAANG stocks. So far, we managed to survive the first hit, the first storm, but if this is a recurring unwinding and a long unwinding, emerging markets like India will also get hit hard.

It is surprising definitely, but I would say 2019 is going to be more a year of mean reversion than anything else. Since 2009 bottom, American markets have had a huge outperformance to the world market. Global market cap moved from $25 trillion to $85 trillion over a span of a decade and the biggest contributor to that was the US market.

Emerging market actually relatively underperformed significantly and this gap between developed market to emerging markets had reached a really really wide point sometime last year and that is reversing. 

So that is one of the reasons why we did not see a selloff even though nearly a trillion dollars were wiped off just from the FAANG stocks in the US. FIIs have been sellers in our market for the last two years, it is not a phenomenon of last three months, six months or something like that. We have been constantly going down in weightage. 

Our market cap probably peaked at around $2.5 trillion and came down to $1.8 trillion. We have also seen quite a bit of wealth erosion and that is why today I am much less worried about global crisis setting off some kind of contagion which can make our markets collapse. I do not think we are facing that kind of scenario today.


In markets we have to look forward, but I will look back and not look back for last one year, but last two years. 2017 was the big year for fund managers, the big year for small cap investors, 80 per cent of the market went higher, 2018, 18 per cent of the market either went lower or it remains stable. What is in store for 2019?

You said it right. In 2018, one of the studies we did showed more than 50 per cent of the stocks fell more than 50 per cent. In that kind of scenario, I do not think your portfolio can be too much different than that. But enter 2019, there are many opportunities available for you to invest and those risks with unreasonable valuations or expectations have been taken out of the market. 

And now, there are a good set of companies available where there can be significant returns made over the next 2-3 years. It might not be immediately in 2019 because some of the concerns are real. It is not like without a reason that the stocks have come off. There are good reasons. But that is where the opportunity lies. But opportunity is dressed in overalls and looks like it's hard work. 


Are you able to find enough businesses which can give a potential earnings growth of 20-25 per cent for the next 2-3 years and are those businesses available reasonably now?

The kind of buckets that we have, is there an opportunity in the market today? There is an opportunity. What are the kinds of opportunities available? What we look for is a good business, good valuation, reasonable valuation and a business tailwind. It is very difficult to find a combination of all these three things present. So, that definitely is very, very minuscule. 

At the same time, there is a little bit of a cyclical headwind in the business or there are some with structural headwinds also. If you are willing to look at those companies, then there is a bucket and a pool of companies where you can stretch your horizon into three and five years of investment and then make good money over there. But you will have to live through next 12 months where the problems are still in the transition phase of turning around. 

For example, even if I just want to put some context to it, PSU banks or real estate developers are going through some real tough times. Those are structural issues, but valuations are not an issue over there. 

It is only an issue of whether and if sentiment will revive. Business tailwinds will come back, there is a going to be a big supply crunch, for sure. The number of players is going to whittle down dramatically in real estate. That is the positive.


Are you happy to buy real estate stocks, do you own a real estate scrip?

No, I do not own any and the only thing I am saying is that is a bucket which requires more than five years of horizon. If you look at something, that has more cyclical business headwinds. Over there, your horizon can be 3-5 years and you can still make good kind of money.

In managing public funds, sometimes we face challenges having a 10-year kind of horizon. We have to look at 3-5 years. Over there, I would be more willing to buy a company which has some cyclical headwind going on and which can be corrected by, say, raw material prices coming down or some amount of stimulus being given to the economy.

Those kinds of situations are more clear and present opportunity for us today.


If we talk about your portfolio positioning in January 2018 versus January 2019, how many stocks have vanished, how many stocks are entry points? In terms of an aggregate approach, is there anything new and different or is it extension of same?

If you remember, we spoke about it last time. There are stocks which are priced to perfection and especially, some of them are on the consumption side. We are out of stocks that were priced to perfection. They are fantastic companies, business tailwinds, everything is going in favour, but there is no room for error. 

So, money has been chasing very, very few ideas in this market. Those few ideas have been really really out-priced now. Now as long as the business tailwind continues, the valuations can sustain. But there is a real risk over there of a significant underperformance with a 3-year point of view.


We have seen that in Eicher. We have started seeing that in a Page. You are referring to pretty much the same obvious stocks?

Yes that is the pool of companies I am referring to, no one particular name but that is the kind of thing, whether it is Page or Eicher or even for that matter Britannia or VIP.


Raamdeo Agrawal told me one thing which is that mehanga roye ek baar sasta roye bar-bar, we are always trying to find something very cheap but it does not work?

No, no, we are not going down the junk road but at the same time Infosys can have 10 years of underperformance, Hindustan Unilever can have 10 years of underperformance. You better be clear about what you are buying and I think the risks are real in terms of underperformance over the next 3-5 years.


You have been bullish on private banks, you have been bullish on select chemical names and you have been bullish on select retail/fashion names. Have those themes extended themselves for 2019?
Private sector banks definitely as a theme continue. But probably now, some of the larger or retail banks are not the ones to be focussed on, corporate banks are better placed. That is where there is a surprise possibility in terms or earnings as well as comfort in terms of valuation. Larger private corporate banks or even for that matter smaller private regional banks provide a very good risk to reward with a five-year point of view if the capex and corporate cycle was to revive.

That should revive whether it is in the next six months or 18 months. That is definitely a fertile area to look at.


You do not think corporate banks is becoming like a consensus trade or maybe I am speaking to all the smart guys who are bullish on corporate banks. I do not know what is this, is this a coincidence or is this a consensus trade now?

Consensus or not, you have to look at how much of the ownership is with the institutions and if you believe that price performance has been fantastic, the performance has not even started yet. Honestly speaking, they are still available. These banks are doing sub-1 per cent ROA. Over the next 3-4 years, the ROAs will move from 0.7-0.8 per cent to 1.2-1.3 per cent and with some bit of leverage, the ROEs can move beyond 15 per cent. 

In that kind of a scenario, all these banks that are quoting between 1-2 per cent can quote anywhere between 2-3 per cent. We are at the beginning of the story, we should not be worried about consensus at this point of time. It is a large pool, FIIs have been selling and I do not see us being in an overcrowded trade by any stretch of imagination.


You own this reputation of being the pharma expert on the stock market when it comes to pharma. We look up to you, we look for your thoughts, when you see an experience like Sun Pharma in 2018, it just shakes you. 


It shakes you that here is the bluest of the blue chip company where corporate governance standards have been raised for a sector and for industry where debt is not a problem, growth may be challenging. But they have never had a debt problem, what does that speak for the sector?

This does not speak for the sector per se. It is a company specific issue, the sector issues were definitely more on the FDA front and I think those are behind us. The corporate governance issues I do not think were completely unknown to the market, it is only that they are out in the public domain today.

They probably did not matter when you were a small company, but today when you are in trillions of rupees of market cap, they matter a lot more because all the global FIIs have taken an exposure to your stock. There is no choice but to get your act together, clean up the books. And you are right. They have an issue... They have a unique situation where they will have to probably get out of this mess in some way, but I do not think it reflects on the sector per se, it reflects more on the company.


We started with John Bogle, but let us go back to our favourite investor Warren Buffett. We love to quote him, we love to talk about him, I wonder if he has to start charging IPs for his quotes...

Yes, he should charge a royalty.


...he will be a richer man by a billion dollar at least.

For sure.

He is pretty much alluding to what you referred to buying good businesses when there is a temporary slowdown or news is bad. Where else do you see this kind of a thesis getting played out?

One space where three-four years of bad period is coming to an end and I believe is agri inputs side. Agri has been in a distress ant it is more because of agri prices being down than anything else. The global cycle also was on a slowdown for the last three years. 


What data are we getting from rural India?

Because there is so much distress that governments will be forced to take action. You want to be positioned for it today.


Focus on where the puck is going to move?

Correct. Because there is distress today, there is no choice but the agri prices to move up over the next 12-18 months. Finally, this is a cycle if a farmer is not getting good realisation for his crop, he will move to another crop that gives him better realisation.

That will eventually create shortage in the other crop and that will make the prices move up. Cyclically, from agri prices point of view, we are close to a bottom and we should move up in the next 12-24 months and that is the local cycle. 

Even globally also, the commentary on large chemical companies has now started being positive and they have started witnessing growth which had come down to close to zero. Now they are talking about 5-7 per cent kind of growth. The confluence of local and global cycle picking up together should play out in agri inputs and we prefer agrochemicals over other inputs.


The thesis of cyclical recovery, the thesis of attractive valuations or reasonable valuations is no longer there in consumers or retail banks or for that matter some of the other obvious names. Some of these opportunities are there in the B2B space, but the challenge with B2B space is that you will not see a huge PE expansion and you will not see a huge margin expansion. I am sure you are aware of that?

So, you are absolutely right, on the consumer front getting a good business at a reasonable valuation is the biggest challenge and even though as a theme, we are really bullish on it. On the B2B consumer side, there is a possibility, I mean I slightly disagree with you over there that PE expansion cannot happen and markets have done funnier things. It is not like it is my base case to bet on a PE rerating over there, but if an upcycle over there extends beyond what the market can imagine right now, they will move to a higher plane in terms of rating. 

So consistency and performance is the most important thing. 


We spoke about a niche pocket which you like within the finance space and that was the small finance bank (SFB). Now the RBI ruling has just acted like a sledgehammer for some names there. Are you still bullish on those names with the RBI red line?

Absolutely. See, they are small in size with Rs 2,000-3,000 crore kind of a loan book size and a similar kind of market cap that is number one. Second, we have to realise they are not NBFCs anymore, they are banks. They have gone through the pain of taking over the cost of the banks, they have started providing SLR, CRR and the cost of converting their branches into a bank branch going from a second floor to a ground floor. 

Those costs are in the numbers. MFI still remains a very-very profitable product while there is a non-MFI SFB also. I am not talking only about MFI SFB. And the SME space is the most lucrative space in terms of lending, you need to have your processes right, you need to do your lending right. 

But they have a platform available from where they can grow 20-25 per cent for a decade. That is the kind of runway available to them. Can these Rs 4,000-5,000 crore loan book become Rs 25,000, Rs 50,000 crore? Sure, it can become, there is no reason why it should not. They have a licence to do that. The ultimate aim is to become a universal bank, SFB is only a stepping stone and some of the vetting is done by RBI for us, they have given licence only to the 10 most deserving guys. 

So out of those 10, I am sure at least two or three will emerge to become far larger and much better banks.


You own the two or three obvious names there, the ones which have just got licence from becoming a microfinance to a small bank. Is that the way to approach it, buy all three, four whatever is available?

Yes, we do own a couple of those names.


Okay, that is the best way to buy them because you do not know eventually which one would be the winner?

No. You go through their history, you see which one survived the crisis best and which one is building its liability franchisee properly, which is the one that is diversifying in its product and geography and you take a call based on that. Still that does not guarantee you success, but at least you know what you are getting into.


What would you say is the outsized bet for this year?

As for outsized bet for this year, we run a concentrated portfolio and each and every bet for us is outsized. I will not say that there is any new stock that we have bet on in a big way, but I think just coming back to the earlier theme, corporate banks and within that small regional banks, there is a real good risk reward available over there.


Autos have corrected and there is a fear that there is a slowdown but if economy comes back, the rural demand comes back, Bajaj Autos and the Eichers and the Mahindra & Mahindra’s of the world will make a comeback. The way you invest, can you spot an opportunity there or this is not the alley where you want to walk? 

No, I am not very keen on looking for opportunities immediately. I believe that the EMI-led growth or leverage led growth is going to witness a slowdown over the next 6-12 months, all this growth was led by the NBFCs and the NBFCs have tightened their purse strings by choice or maybe not by choice. 

Because of that, growth will slow down over there. I would rather go to where the end consumer is buying out of his own pocket instead of taking loans for that.


The NBFCs have avoided a cannon ball, but the cruel fact is that look there was an asset liability mismatch, they were borrowing short and they were lending long. This setup has broken, this created opportunity for good players to gain market share. Are you looking at buying something in the NBFC space?

Again, no. It is not...


But that is the place you would be hunting right now, right?

No, I think the problems have just started. 


Even in HFCs?

Maybe not in HFCs. In some of the HFCs, the asset liability mismatch is not such a big issue. Even though you sell 25-year payment but those are actually seven, eight year products and some amount of ALM mismatch is necessary for you to make your ROE over there. 

I am not buying any HFCs at the moment, but I do not think the extent of problem in some of the HFCs will be as big as some of the other NBFCs that are let us say developer loans or any such thing. I think there is a decently chunky real estate developer portfolio which is coming up and it will be recognised as an NPA over the next 12 to 24 months and the conditions are not going to get any easier in terms of funding for the NBFCs. 

I would wait, it is a situation which is in flux, I would wait to see which are the players that are going to survive, which are the players that are going to get hit and I will wait for a year or so before I can say now the NBFC crisis is well and truly behind us and we can place our bets over here.


In 2013, when we met you said if I get a million dollars right now, I would invest it right away. I can see and smell that kind of an opportunity in the market. If you get a million dollars from a client after this interview, do you have the conviction to invest it right away in your set of stocks or will you wait? 

Investing is not an issue, managing the expectation is an issue... I will invest only when there is a crisis in the market or I will invest only when I get the best combination of opportunity, entrepreneur and valuation. 

For that kind of a money, there are very few opportunities in the market but if you are somebody who has a compulsion to look for opportunities and if there is no crisis, ex of crisis I think the valuations are okay, what we need is some revival in growth going forward. 

If that is the case, a reasonable expectation of return can be met. Let us not get carried away, can I make 10x return or something like that in four, five years, surely but probably I would be more comfortable maybe three months, six months down the line where more water has flown under the bridge. 

But investing and deploying in the equities is not an issue. In fact, we are fully invested, we will probably go fully invested into the elections and we will not change our strategy just because there is an event. That can have a big impact on the market, we are planning to live through it.


The way you manage money, the election would be just one of the events?

Yes, I mean, it matters a lot to a speculator and for an investor who has a longer term horizon. I have to only see whether it is going to provide an opportunity to enter or is it going to provide me an opportunity to exit.

NEW DELHI: Indian stocks showed up in green early Monday, in light of tepid gains in Asian markets, after China grew at 6.4 per cent in the December quarter.

The world's second-largest economy grew by about 6.6 per cent in 2018, according to official data, the slowest annual pace China has seen since 1990.

Experts said the market was expecting weak Chinese numbers and now Beijing may announce more fiscal stimulus to support its economy, which is already reeling under the Sino-US trade war.

Back home, gains in IT, bank and financial stocks amid hopes of healthy December quarter earnings helped the market stay in positive territory.

Oil's softness in the global market also spurred buying. The rupee, however, lost weight, which opened 15 paise down at 71.34 against the dollar. 

The BSE Sensex rallied 210 points, or 0.58 per cent, to 36,597 around 9.45 am. The Nifty was up 51 points, or 0.47 per cent, at 10,958. 

Market analysts see a strong opportunity in select stocks in this current market. 

Based on brokerage recommendations, here is a list of 10 stocks that can potentially generate gains over the next 2-3 weeks. 


Mazhar Mohammad, Chief Strategist – technical research and trading advisory, Chartviewindia.in

Dabur India| Buy| Target price: Rs 439| Stop loss: Rs 416
This counter appears to have formed a short-term bottom as it is repeatedly attracting buying interest around Rs 417 levels. In the last couple of sessions, the bulls have gained upper hand in this counter, which traded close to Rs 418. "Sustaining above Rs 420, it can make an attempt to test its interim top of Rs 440. Positional traders can create fresh longs with a stop below Rs 416 on a closing basis and look for an initial target of Rs 439," Mohammad said.


Hero MotoCorp| Buy| Target price: Rs 3,118| Stop loss: Rs 2,855
After retracing around 80 per cent of its last leg of rally from the lows of Rs 2,648, this counter appears to be making an attempt to form a base around Rs 2,856 for quite some time. If it bottoms out around these levels, it can easily retrace by a minimum of 50 per cent of the fall from the highs of Rs 3,380. "As the risk-reward ratios looks favourable, in anticipation of a pullback move, positional traders are advised to go long for an initial target of Rs 3,118, with a stop below Rs 2,855 on a closing basis," Mohammad said.


Gajendra Prabu, Technical Analyst, HDFC Securities

HCL Technologies| Buy| Target price: Rs 1,060| Stop loss: Rs 918
The stock has validated the Doji candle pattern formed on a weekly chart in the previous week (moved above candle’s high), which is confirmation of bullish reversal. MUMBAI: India Inc should aim towards a representation target of improving the gender diversity on boards to 30%, something in line with the 30% Club campaign in the UK, said several eminent corporate leaders ET spoke to. Some others argued strongly for more female members in boardrooms, but said setting an immediate target would be impractical and the focus should be on gradual progression.

“There is nothing like a target for business people and I believe aspiring to have 30% representation of women will certainly add value to Indian boards, provided there is no compromise on competence,” said former Britannia managing director Vinita Bali. “If more women on boards is not happening organically or naturally while there are enough competent women in the system, a special impetus (like a representation target) in order to get focused attention is the only way in which change will happen,” added Bali, who has been a board member at several global and Indian companies.

“Initially, women were inducted to meet regulatory requirement but now chairmen and promoters have realised that women’s participation improves effectiveness of boards,” said Arun Duggal, chairman of ratings firm ICRA.

Agencies
Duggal said individual companies should set their own targets for board composition and succession planning, rather than having a common goal.

Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw, chairperson of Biocon, however, isn’t too much concerned about the percentage. She said: “We should stress more on independence than the percentage of women. Many public boards are already looking at improving their gender balance and such companies are more successful than others in terms of governance.”

Biocon chairperson Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw feels that companies should stress more on independence than the percentage of women. 
Last year, the Securities and Exchange Board of India asked India’s top 500 listed companies to appoint at least one “independent” woman director by April 1, 2019, as per new governance guidelines notification by the market regulator.

Earlier, the Companies Act of 2013 mandated a certain class of companies to have at least one woman director. Sebi, in compliance with the Act, made this compulsory from October 2014.

The 30% Club was established in the UK in 2010 to campaign for greater representation of women — a minimum of 30% — on the boards of FTSE 100 companies. The club is currently led by Brenda Trenowden.

Some champions of gender diversity, like Zia Mody, founder and managing partner of AZB & Partners, feel that India cannot jump to 30% immediately. “It has to be gradual. It is not just about setting a target but how you reach there is important,” she said. Companies should be pushing women and creating capacity, she added. “The top and middle management — largely the male — have to understand the importance of this and mentor women to reach there,” she added.


Zia Mody, founder and managing partner of AZB & Partners, feel that India cannot jump to 30% immediately. 
Harsh Mariwala, chairman of consumer products company Marico, also has a similar view. “You can't impose a target. But it will be a gradual progress. Realisation will happen depending on the quality of women directors and to what extent they add value,” he said.


Harsh Mariwala, chairman of Marico, says, “You can't impose a target. it will be a gradual progress." 
Numbers show that there has been a consistent increase in women’s representation in corporate India over the past three years — from 25% in 2016 to 30% in 2017 and 31% in 2018 — as per the Working Mother & AVTAR Best Companies survey for women in India. This indicates an increasing intent among companies on gender inclusion, an extrapolation of which would be gender balance at leadership levels, said Saundarya Rajesh, founder-president of the AVTAR Group, a diversity strategist.

In 2008, Norway mandated 40% representation of women on corporate boards, and several European countries followed with a 30-35% target. The European Commission has a target of 40% female representation on listed company boards by 2020.

Mumbai: Shares of Britannia Industries is likely to be included in the Nifty in the upcoming index review in February as its free float market cap has increased, said analysts. Hindustan Petroleum Corporation or Bharti Infratel are likely to be excluded from the Nifty with probability being higher for exit of HPCL, they added. 

The changes are likely to come into effect from the April series, with announcement likely sometime in February. 

"Considering the average free float market capitalisation since August 1, 2018, Britannia is most likely to replace Hindustan Petroleum Corporation from the Nifty 50 stocks," said retail brokerage ICICIdirect in a note. 

According to guidelines, a stock may be replaced from an index in case there are compulsory changes like corporate actions, delisting etc, in which case, stock having largest free float market capitalisation and satisfying other requirements related to liquidity, turnover and free float will be considered for inclusion. The second condition is if a better stock is available in the replacement pool. The stock which is to be included in the Nifty should have at least 1.5 times the free float market capitalisation of the stock that is to be included.

NEW DELHI: If the overnight drop in US stocks and technical charts are any signal, domestic market is likely to open on a tepid note, with the Nifty50 facing resistance in 10,950-10,970 range. Third quarter results of index heavyweight ITC would be in focus.

Let's check out what all might matter to Dalal Street on Wednesday:


Singapore trading sets stage for flat start 
Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 6 points, or 0.05 per cent, lower at 10,926, indicating a flat-to-negative start for the Nifty50.



Nifty forms ‘Hanging Man’ candle
Nifty50 on Tuesday snapped a 5-day winning streak and ended up forming a ‘Hanging Man’ candle on the daily chart, suggesting bulls might have started losing control. The Nifty50 structure suggests that the index still has potential to stretch towards 11,000-11,070 range to complete its last leg of the Ending Diagonal pattern. But such a move is unlikely to be a smooth one, said Gaurav Ratnaparkhi, Senior Technical Analyst at Sharekhan.


Asian shares inch lower
Asian stocks edged down on Wednesday on mounting signs of slowing global growth and anxiety over a yet-unresolved Sino-US trade dispute, Reuters reported Japan's Nikkei dropped 0.7 per cent while MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan dipped 0.1 per cent.


Oil prices stabilise
Oil prices stabilised on Wednesday after steep falls in the previous session, when markets were dragged down by growing concerns about an economic slowdown, Reuters reported. International Brent crude oil futures were at $61.58 per barrel, up 8 cents, or 0.1 percent, from their last close.


US stocks dropped overnight
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 301.87 points, or 1.22 per cent, to 24,404.48, the S&P500 index lost 37.81 points, or 1.42 per cent, to 2,632.9 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 136.87 points, or 1.91 percent, to 7,020.36, Reuters reported.


Fed has to rethink tightening: Dalio
The Federal Reserve and other major central banks are right to rethink their plans to tighten monetary policy in 2019 as global growth slows, according to the investors and former policy makers attending the Davos summit.


ITC, RCom to report Q3 results
ITC, Reliance Communications (RCom), InterGlobe Aviation, Radico Khaitan, Vijaya Bank, Bharti Infratel, JM Financial, Pidilite, Ujjivan, Raymond, Can Fin Home, United Spirits and DB Corp will be among companies, which will announce their December quarter results on Wednesday.


Britannia may join Nifty club in Feb
Britannia Industries is likely to be included in the Nifty in the upcoming index review in February as its free float market cap has increased, said analysts. Hindustan Petroleum Corp or Bharti Infratel are likely to be excluded from the index with probability being higher for exit of HPCL, they added.


RIL gets CCI nod to acquire Hathway, DEN
Mukesh Ambani-owned Reliance Industries (RIL) has received a go-ahead from the Competition Commission of India to acquire majority stakes in two of the country’s largest cable operators, DEN Networks and Hathway Cable & Datacom.


Edelweiss, IIFL look to buy IL&FS unit
IL&FS Investment Managers has drawn interest from Edelweiss, India Infoline and Altico Capital, an industry source close to the development said.


Re tumbles 16 paise to 71.44
The rupee skidded by 16 paise Tuesday – its third straight session of loss – to close at 71.44 against the US dollar amid strengthening of the greenback and heavy selling in domestic equities. Concerns over slowing global growth and foreign capital outflows weighed on the local unit, forex traders said. The rupee opened higher at 71.22 but came under selling pressure.


DIIs sell Rs 84 crore worth of equities
Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) sold Rs 79 crore worth of domestic stocks on Tuesday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net sellers to the tune of Rs 84 crore, data suggested.

PNB: State-owned Punjab National Bank (PNB) said Agyey Kumar Azad has taken charge as executive director of the bank. Prior to joining PNB, he was general manager in Bank of India.


Syngene International: Contract research and manufacturing firm Syngene International Tuesday reported a 6.09 per cent rise in consolidated net profit to Rs 87 crore for the third quarter ended December 31, 2018.


NMDC: State-owned iron ore miner NMDC announced resumption of operations at its sponge iron unit in Paloncha, Telangana.

NEW DELHI: The Nifty FMCG index was trading in the green in Wednesday's afternoon session. 

Shares of Colgate-Palmolive (India) (up 1.86 per cent), Britannia Industries (up 1.59 per cent), Hindustan Unilever (up 1.45 per cent) and GlaxoSmithKline Consumer Healthcare (up 1.01 per cent) were the top performers in the index. 

Jubilant Foodworks (up 0.86 per cent), ITC (up 0.76 per cent) and Marico (up 0.32 per cent) too were trading higher. 

The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.79 per cent up at 30,747.35 around 12:00 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 0.45 points at 10,922.30 while the BSE Sensex was down 27.46 points at 36,417.18. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 27 were trading in the green, while 23 were in the red. 

Shares of YES Bank, ICICI Prudential Life Insurance Company, Sun Pharma, Ashok Leyland, Wipro, Zee Entertainment, ITC, SAIL, SBI, Axis Bank, Vedanta, Bank of Baroda, Tata Motors and RIL were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

NEW DELHI: Less than 10 days are left for interim Budget 2019, and Dalal Street is still divided over how big an event it would be from the market’s viewpoint. Analysts believe that consumer-facing stocks could hog limelight in the coming days. They are also finding private banks attractively priced.

Finance Minister Arun Jaitley in a recent interview acknowledged some economic challenges that “can’t afford to wait” and the necessity to address some of them.

Amid confusion among investors on how position themselves ahead of the key event, Sharekhan has picked its pre-Budget portfolio. The brokerage sees Bata India, Britannia Industries, Century Plyboards, Dabur India, Escorts, Future Lifestyle Fashions, GNA Axles, Hindustan Unilever, ICICI Bank and V-Guard Industries as ‘buys’ amid high probability of a nation-wide direct benefit scheme for farmers and a recalibration of income tax structure for middle class.

Jaitley’s statement indicated that a package to support the farm sector was likely to be announced very soon, most likely in the upcoming budget or by early March, said Nomura India in a note. This was because the election commission would announce general elections dates in the first week of March, which would trigger the model code of conduct.

Announcements to allay rural distress can push rural consumption sectors, but hurt capital goods, infrastructure and construction sectors, said brokerage Anand Rathi Financial Services.

Abhimanyu Sofat of IIFL sees momentum building into private banking space.

“Anything, which leads to better growth and more disposable income, is the play that one should be looking for in the budget perspective. It would make sense to look at private sector banks. HDFC numbers looked quite decent to us and a revival in capex gives opportunity in terms of getting stocks like Larsen & Toubro at lower level” the expert said.

Foreign brokerage CLSA said ITC should see some relief rally as Budget is unlikely to tinker with tobacco taxation.

“The tampering or the changes in the indirect tax rates would be left with the GST council. So while there is always a chance that the GST council may take that up in its next meeting, what we have seen is that over the last 12-13 months that the tobacco taxation has been quite stable. The volume growth has therefore picked up. There is a very low likelihood of the central government making any changes to the tobacco taxation in Budget,” Mahesh Nandurkar, India Strategist, CLSA, said.

Meanwhile, Ganeshram Jayaraman of Spark Capital Advisors, said that since we were still in a grinding phase, one must stick to companies, which have delivered across the cycles.

“Value first is our priority. We are kind of wary of cyclicals, NBFCs, government-spend dependent companies, especially government capex-dependent companies. We are wary of larger-ticket sized discretionary plays. It is more a safety-first portfolio strategy, which we have been adopting and that kind of continues,” he said.

NEW DELHI: Dalal Street has had a weak start to an extremely important week, that will see the unveiling of the Interim Budget, rollover of F&O contracts, US Fed’s rate-setting meeting and some major earnings announcements.

The Finance Minister will present the Vote on Account to Parliament on February 1, Friday, for the first three months of the new financial year before the new government presents a full-fledged Budget in July. 

The domestic stock market may have to endure bouts of volatility as January series futures & options contracts expire on Thursday. Then, earnings of some top companies like Axis Bank, Bank of Baroda, HDFC, HCL Technologies, Bharti Airtel, Hero MotoCorp, Bajaj Auto, ICICI Bank and State Bank of India are lined up. The US Fed will hold its first monetary policy meet of 2019 on January 29-30.

A 26 per cent annual compounded return can grow your portfolio 10 times in 10 years! Sounds mouth-watering? 

Ambit Capital on Tuesday listed 30 ‘great’ stocks that it said can multiply investor wealth by 10 times in the coming years.

The list included Nilkamal, La Opala RG, Avenue Supermarts, Maruti Suzuki, Kansai Nerolac, PVR, Venky’s India, Sudarshan Chemicals, Torrent Power, Sheela Foam, Godrej Agrovet, JB Chemical, WABCO India, Heidelberg Cements, Dr Lal Pathlabs, Advanced Enzymes, Johnson Control, CCL Products, Natco Pharma and Jyothy Lab. 

Seven other stocks on the list were Timken India, Atul, Whirlpool India, Britannia Industries, Sundram Fasteners, 3M India, Kajaria Ceramics.


OthersSource: Ambit Capital
The brokerage defined ‘great’ stocks as those which have been showing incremental capex, efficiency in capital employed, pricing discipline, steady cash generation, PAT improvement, solid balance sheet and steady improvement and above-median sales.

The greatness framework includes companies that invest capital, turn investment into sales, turn sales into profit, turn profit into balance sheet strength, turn all of that into free cash flow and invest free cash flow again.

Back-tested data showed such stocks have delivered superior returns in the longer run. During 2004-19, such companies outperformed the entire stock universe by 3.5 per cent per annum (on an average) and the BSE500 index by 5.7 per cent, Ambit said.


OthersSource: Ambit  Capital
To determine whether a particular stock is cheap or not, Ambit categorises these stocks into buckets based on their relative attractiveness on valuations with respect to their own history.

“We compare these firms with respect to their five-year average valuations on three metrics – price-to-book, price-to-earnings and EV/Ebitda.”

The brokerage found only 21 of these stocks inexpensive, but said from a long-term perspective, all 30 remain potential ten-bagger candidates. 

Ambit has bottom-up coverage on Maruti Suzuki and PVR with ‘buy’ ratings.

A similar 10-bagger list published by the brokerage on January 15, 2018 slipped 9 per cent in last one year. 

Ambit also released a list of 15 smallcaps than can become ten-baggers over time. The list included Bhansali Engineering, Menon Bearings, Kennametal India, Lumax Industries, Matrimony.com, Foseco India, NR Agarwal Industries, Harita Seating, Multibase India, Valiant Organics, Orient Refractories, Shemaroo Entertainment, India Glycols, Ruchil Décor and Deccan Cement. 

As a rider, the brokerage said it is not necessary all the stocks highlighted through this process are going to be individually ten-baggers. “We ask investors to own the portfolio for 10 years. Here we churn this equally-weighted portfolio annually. The objective behind this process is to try and generate 26 per cent CAGR over a 10-year holding period by buying companies that are improving on ‘greatness’ count as well as on accounting scores,” the brokerage said.

Our house view has been positive on consumption and that gets reinforced after the budget. Incrementally we are 
  
  
  more bullish on auto after a very strong correction last year, Gautam Duggad, Head of Research, MOSL, tells ET Now. Edited excerpts:

Do you think the Dewan Housing issue has the potential to snowball into an IL&FS kind of a situation?
It is an evolving situation and as we have seen with IL&FS crisis, markets do get nervous around it. We will have to keep watching what happens there because it has implication for the other participants in the system. It is very tough to take a call right now. As far as NBFCs are concerned, the cost of fund situation has gone up and liquidity has been tightening for last couple of months. 

Our view has been that in 2019, it is very important to be cautious on this space. We have HDFC and LIC Housing Finance in our model portfolio and that is what we will stick with. We did increase weight on LIC Housing Finance recently post budget along with increasing the weights on some of the banks and consumption stocks.

What is the outlook is on the consumption space? We did see that a major push came to the space as a whole. Purely from consumption standpoint, how do you see the overall metrics changing and spending picking up as a whole?
We have been quite positive on consumption. Leaving aside the Budget, in last 15-20 days, the results of consumption-oriented stocks have been extremely strong -- be it staples or discretionary. While valuations are expensive, these are the stocks which are going to outperform even in current year because we are going into an event which is very important from the markets point of view. Our view is that one should be a little more defensive, going into the election this year because markets wise, valuations are not very favourable. 

Secondly, the budget just reinforces the very strong consumption environment. Please remember that Rs 6,000 per annum is not a one-off kind of thing and it is going to be very difficult for any government in future to withdraw the scheme. 

Logically, one should only expect that this Rs 6,000 will just keep on increasing either in line with inflation or some such number every year. So, it plays a very strong stimulus for consumption. At Rs 75,000 crore, it is not a very big sum, but given the structural nature of this kind of handouts, these are going to help consumption even in the long run, more so, from low-ticket consumption view point. 

We have been very positive on Hindustan Lever, Titan, Britannia and Pidilite and that view stays. In fact, Titan just reported on Friday a very stellar set of numbers. Another quarter of earnings upgrade and market share gains which are continuing. Our house view has been positive on consumption and that gets reinforced after the budget. Incrementally we are more bullish on auto after a very strong correction last year. 

We like the four-wheeler space more. Given the relatively low competitive intensity and very sharp correction in Maruti that we have seen in the last 12 months, we have increased the weight on Maruti in our model portfolio on Friday.


What is your view on the broader end of the market? Do you think that when it comes to the general trend this year, it is going to be a pre-May and a post-May sort of trend given the general elections? Would you approach midcaps very differently in the first and the second half?
Absolutely. I mean this will be a story of two halves, however, clichéd this may sound. As far as midcap is concerned, I agree that in last 12 months, we have seen midcaps getting battered. It has brought down the premium that midcaps had to largecap. If you go back 12 months in January 18, the premium of midcap to largecap was roughly 50% to 60% and that has now come down to 10-15% at index level. 

While it is still at a premium and therefore slightly tricky to tackle, given the correction that we have seen, there are some interesting bottom-up opportunities in midcaps which are now available. This was not the case 12 months back, where touching midcap was very difficult given the valuations that they were trading at. 

Now that has opened up a bit of a space for any stock allocator to hunt for bottom-up midcap ideas. Secondly, as far as broader market view is concerned, this is a year which is going to be in a tight range with elevated volatility because at 10,700, 10,800, we are still trading at around 17.5 to 18.5 time one year forward band which is not very cheap. 

At the same time, it is not exorbitantly expensive. The only thing that has changed in the last one month is that the corporate earnings have been very strong whether it is on the consumption side or whether it is on the corporate bank side. Our view is that this is a year where you have to be a little more defensive, play through three-four important sectors which are consumption, private banks, select NBFCs, auto and IT to an extent. 

I am still not very positive on other sectors which are more capex driven or dependent on the economic cycle. Though we have been hearing about green shoots in capex, it is not yet reflected in numbers. My approach is to be in sectors where there is quality and earnings visibility. I am willing to make a mistake on valuation rather than on business side. 


And you think these parameters that you just talked about are all conjoining for autos right now? Within autos, while valuations have corrected off the peaks, where do you see some growth finally kicking in?
We are not going to see any big recovery in auto in a hurry. The stock price correction has given enough room now to do more detailed bottom-up analysis on a lot of these stocks which were very expensive 12 months back. What we like in that space are more four- wheelers given that the competitive intensity is relatively less intense there compared to two- wheelers. 

Secondly, for a stock like Maruti which has seen big combination of headwinds battering its margin in the third quarter, incrementally we are expecting those margins to gradually inch upward starting from fourth quarter itself. That is one stock which is our top idea in that space.

The other tactical play could be M&M given that again that stock has seen a big correction in the last 12 months and now that there are some handouts for farmers, for middle class, sentiment could be positive around M&M while valuations are very cheap. 

You may not see any big earnings upgrade in that space but there could be some re-rating there given that the broader context for the auto and farming side has changed a little bit after the budget. In two-wheelers, we are still very cautious on both Bajaj and Hero. I still think that there is very little room left for re-rating unless we see a big margin or a big volume surprise there, which is very difficult right now. 

Eicher is one name where incrementally I am now more positive. Even there, one has to keep watching the RE number on a monthly basis before getting too excited. We have seen what happens to the two-wheeler stocks in the last decade after their glory days are over. I would not be in a hurry to even buy Eicher. Right now to summarise our view on auto, we are more positive on four-wheelers.

NEW DELHI: Headline indices Sensex and Nifty opened cautiously on Thursday ahead of RBI's monetary policy outcome, but rose further soon, backed by gains in pharma, bank, IT and FMCG heavyweights. 

The Reserve Bank of India will announce its monetary policy decision before noon today. A section of analysts expect RBI to keep key lending rate for commercial banks unchanged at 6.5 per cent for the third time in succession but change its stance from 'calibrated tightening' to 'neutral'. 

A fall in global crude oil prices also influenced the sentiment while global cues were broadly mixed. 

Asian share markets were in a muted mood on Thursday and looked set for a sleepy session with China still on holiday and no major economic data on the diary, Reuters reported. 

The BSE Sensex index rose 150 points, whereas the Nifty50 hovered near 11,100 in early trade. 

Around 9:30 am, the Sensex was trading 143 points, or 0.39 per cent, up at 37,118, while the Nifty index was 33 points, or 0.29 per cent, up at 11,095.

BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices were 0.27 per cent and 0.18 per cent up, respectively.

Sun Pharma shares jumped 3 per cent and were leading the pack of Sensex gainers at that time. HCL Tech, Bajaj Auto, Tata Motors, Hero MotoCorp, ONGC and Reliance Industries were trading with decent gains.

Tata Steel, on the other hand, declined over 1 per cent to lead the pack of Sensex losers. Vedanta, Bharti Airtel, IndusInd Bank and HDFC, too, were in the red.

Pharma, IT and auto were the top gainers among the sectoral indices on BSE, rising up to 1 per cent.

The metal pack, however, fell 1 per cent on losses in shares of JSW Steel, Hindalco, Tata Steel and Vedanta.

Meanwhile, Foreign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 695 crore worth of domestic stocks on Wednesday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net buyers to the tune of Rs 525 crore, data suggested. 

Tata Motors, SAIL, Grasim Industries, Adani Enterprises, Adani Green, Apex Frozen, Bajaj Electricals, Britannia Industries, MRF, PTC India and Welspun Corp are among companies set to announce their December quarter results today.

RBI policy outcome today
The outcome of the sixth bi-monthly monetary policy will be out today. Deviating from the practice of releasing the resolution of six-member MPC in the afternoon, the RBI will place it on its website at 11.45 am on February 7.


Asian shares doze amid dull data
Asian share markets were in a muted mood on Thursday and looked set for a sleepy session with China still on holiday and no major economic data on the diary, Reuters reported. Japan’s Nikkei dipped 0.2 percent, while E-Mini futures for the S&P 500 were off 0.06 percent in very thin trade.

US oil prices dipped on Thursday after US crude inventories rose and as production levels in the country stayed at record levels, but OPEC-led supply cuts and the crisis in Venezuela supported markets.US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures were at $53.82 per barrel, down 19 cents, or 0.35 per cent, from their last settlement.


US economy in a good place: Fed Powell 
Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said on Wednesday the US economy remains in a good place and has proved resilient so far to shocks like the British decision to leave the European Union.


US stocks edged lower
US stocks edged lower on Wednesday as videogame makers gave disappointing revenue forecasts and investors awaited developments on US-China trade relations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 21.22 points, or 0.08 per cent, to 25,390.3, the S&P500 index lost 6.09 points, or 0.22 per cent, to 2,731.61 and the Nasdaq Composite index dropped 26.80 points, or 0.36 per cent, to 7,375.28.

RBI worry over FPI-NRI route merger
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has expressed concerns over the market regulator’s proposal to merge investment route of non-resident Indians (NRIs) with foreign portfolio investor (FPI) route, said three people privy to the development. The central bank is against the plan in its current form because the regulations that govern both the modes of inflows are separate, and clubbing the two would cause a regulatory haze.

NEW DELHI: Indian equities suffered heavy losses on Friday, following weak trends in most global peers, as bleak economic data from Europe and lack of any sign of a resolution to the US-China trade tussle spooked investor sentiment. 

The European Commission on Thursday slashed its growth forecast for the euro zone this year and the next, stoking concerns that a global slowdown is spreading to Europe as businesses and investors grapple with trade friction, Reuters reported. 

“The market is reacting to global cues in the absence of any significant domestic trigger,” said Pankaj Pandey, Head of Research at ICICI Securities. Besides, investors are taking extremely calculated steps ahead of the general elections. 

Nilesh Shah, MD, Kotak AMC, said there is wariness in the market about the general elections, which may cause some volatility in the short-term. 

Sensex plunged 425 points, or 1.15 per cent, to close at 36,546, extending the losses into the second successive session. Nifty suffered a loss of 126 points, or 1.14 per cent, to close at 10,943.


Let's take a look at the highlights of Friday's session:

Rs 1.70 lakh crore gone todayFreaky Friday erased over Rs 1.7 lakh crore of investors’ wealth in a single day as cumulative wealth of BSE-listed firms plunged to Rs 1,41,04,729 crore on Friday from Rs 1,42,74,785 crore on Thursday. 


Tata Motors in deep painA record Rs 26,961 crore loss in December quarter triggered a sharp selloff in shares of Tata Motors. The scrip fell 29.45 per cent to hit a low of Rs 129 on NSE. On BSE, it fell 22.41 per cent to hit Rs 141.90. This was the second worst intra-day fall for the stock in its history. The scrip fell 40.50 per cent on February 2, 1993. However, the scrip pared some losses and closed 17.28 per cent down at Rs 151 on BSE. In a single day, the company lost Rs 9,124 crore on BSE to Rs 43,685 crore from Rs 52,809 crore on Thursday. 


Reliance ADAG group shares gainShares of Anil Ambani-led Reliance ADAG Group companies recovered after the recent drubbings. Reliance Capital (up 11.23 per cent), Reliance Power (up 9.55 per cent), Reliance Infrastructure (up 6.54 per cent), Reliance Naval and Engineering (up 5.78 per cent) and Reliance Communications (up 4.82 per cent) closed with solid gains. In a media statement, Reliance ADAG group accused L&T and Edelweiss entities of "illegal, motivated and wholly-unjustified actions" in invoking share pledges of listed Reliance Group company and selling them in the open market causing a fall of nearly 55 per cent of Reliance Group shares over four days.


M&M falls after Q3Shares of Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M) closed 2.64 per cent down at Rs 683 on BSE as the company reported a 60 per cent YoY jump in consolidated profit at Rs 1,476 crore. The stock fell as the company’s operating profit margin fell to 13.2 per cent from 14.7 per cent in the same quarter last year. 


Jet shares fall 5%Extending the losses into the second session in a row, shares of Jet Airways (India) closed 4.78 per cent down at Rs 225. The company on Friday said its board would meet on February 14 to approve the unaudited financial statements for the third quarter and nine months ended December 31. 


Britannia shares fall slowdown fearsShares of Britannia Industries fell 3.23 per cent to Rs 3,109 after it acknowledged a slowdown in the market place in recent months in a BSE filing. The company, however, expects that the steps taken in the Interim Budget to boost rural consumption would help it neutralise this slowdown. Global brokerage Macquarie has maintained an 'underperform' view on the stock, with a target price of Rs 2,335 per share, highlighting that the domestic volume growth at nearly 7 per cent was below estimates.


Raymond jumps 5%After six days of successive fall, Raymond closed Friday's session 4.85 per cent higher at Rs 687.25 after it gave clarification about related party transactions. Shares of the company plunged the most in over two years on Thursday after media reported that it had “curious transactions” with an entity owned by its promoter. Later, the company said all of its related party transactions are undertaken in compliance with laws.


78 stocks signal potential riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 78 counters on the BSE. Among them were, Bharti Airtel, Rain Industries, Vivimed Labs, UltraTech Cement, Birla Cable and Parag Milk Foods. On the other hand, 56 stocks, including Tata Motors, Indian Oil Corporation, Mindtree, HDFC and Voltas showed bearish crossovers on BSE.
