This is the time to deploy cash now. You should be looking at good quality midcaps, smallcaps and 
  
  
  there is safety there. They will fall if the Nifty falls, but the ability to handle those corrections is much easier in the longer term, said Sanjay Dutt, Director, Quantum Securities, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:


Last time when we met the world was bearish, you were bullish. You got it right. Now that the world is bullish, are you getting bearish?
I am not getting bearish but we must keep in mind that on a broader macro basis, we are not out of the woods yet because there are a lot of macro headwinds in India at present. What we are seeing right now is an oversold rally and also we are part of the emerging market basket where we have lagged for quite some time in the last few months. Now we are doing a catch-up and that is flows are coming in. 

From now onwards, it is going to be a function of earnings and flows. Earnings being company specific and if emerging market flows carry on, markets would seek higher levels. More than the Nifty or market seeking higher levels, a lot of stock-specific opportunities in buying would come in and that is already happening. So, it will probably carry on. But the key issue is that on economy basis, we have still got a problem. Private sector capex has not picked up as yet. Inflation, is benign but at the same time, we may not have a 7% GDP growth rate. It is probably closer to 6.5% according to me if one does a proper calculation. 

So everything is not gung-ho but what we are seeing right now is being oversold in an under-invested situation where people are coming in to buy. 


Right now, market is working on three assumptions; one, we will get a favourable market-friendly political verdict; two, interest rates will not move up and; three, flows into emerging markets will increase. What happens to the market if the news flow turns adverse? 
That is a valid point and it links to my hypothesis at this point of time that Nifty would fall off substantially if we have some real political shocks coming in. I easily see 10% fall in Nifty in case the government that is formed is not what the market is pricing in right now. The Nifty rally is very concentrated. It is dependant on a bunch of seven-ten stocks which had a very stretched valuations at this point of time -- HDFC Bank or Kotak Bank. These are trading at phenomenal price to book, phenomenal earnings that you are factoring in. They will really come off in a big way and people would not know how to get to the exit door if any negative news flow comes in. If you want to deploy, you should be deploying cash now. You should be looking at good quality midcaps, smallcaps and there is safety there. They will fall if the Nifty falls, but the ability to handle those kind of corrections is much easier in the longer term, rather than seeing HDFC Bank correcting 10-15% and then not knowing whether to sell it or to hold on. One needs to be very cautious in case all the positives that are priced in do not fall in place in the next three-six months.


One of the top trends on twitter is how Mukesh Ambani has rescued younger brother Anil and saved him from going to jail for non-payment to Ericsson. Do you find merit in any of the ADAG Group businesses like Reliance Power, Reliance Capital?
Out of the group’s entire basket of stocks, I am positively inclined towards Reliance Capital. I would like to disclose that I have a position there. There is phenomenal value in that stock and to my understanding the focus for the next generation lies in that business at this point of time and that is one business which even Mr Anil Ambani has been very savvy right from the early days when he was part of the integrated group. 

That is one place to be but obviously volatility is your friend out there. We saw it at Rs 190 odd about a week-10 days back and suddenly we saw it at Rs 162. So, on a very bad day, that stock could definitely be bought. Within the group, there is a very small company where I have a position. It is Reliance Home Finance. It has a phenomenal franchise. It is a good business on ground but because of the negativity surrounding the group, it is trading at a pittance at this point of time. These are the two best bets in the group for the next two years.


There is growing pessimism when it comes to the auto space as a whole. Maruti yesterday talked about production cuts. Do you find selective names look appealing here?
No, not as yet. The pessimism is justified and most of the pessimism also already in the price right now but there might just be one last selloff where we see some of the stocks falling off the cliff by 5%, 10% or 20% in a few sessions when one or two of the big boys with large holdings may just decide to unload. 

But even after that, I don’t know if one can expect Maruti to suddenly bounce back 20%-30% in the next two-three months. The volumes have plateaued month on month, quarter on quarter. I have been saying for quite some time the industries have seen some kind of structural shift in product lifecycles. Whether we are moving towards EVs or new technologies, is also bothering the industries. 

Obviously, people are questioning the entire concept of owning high-end cars when you are talking about share rides of Uber and Ola. We have seen this trend in the west and I do not see the reason why this trend will not fall in place here. With improvement in urban transportation, you cannot see the kind of numbers that you have seen in Maruti, M&M over the last two-three years. These companies will have to reposition their models. Cutting a long story short, I would not really want to be overweight these stocks at this point.


What are the feelers that you are getting about the upcoming elections? Is NDA coming back to power and is that the assumption that the market is also working with which some believe to be one of the factors behind the March rally?
Yes, that is exactly what I said just now. The market is going by the assumption that Prime Minister Modi would lead the next government if that does not come through, markets are in for a huge sell-off. That will be a very rapid selloff in two-three days. Everyone who has been long will lose his short and that is the board in Delhi also. People believe that they will get the numbers in place, NDA would be back in power and that is the assumption that is priced in as far as the markets are concerned. 

If a coalition comes to power, the uncertainty around who is going to be the Prime Minister or what is going to be the shape of the government will make the market panic and it may fall. But in this fall, there will be some real buying opportunities but if you are long and then you stuck in that period, then God save me because I am also long. So God save all of us who have invested because that is going to be really a volatile period and one would not know what to do because it is priced in and the prices right now.


Everyone is of the view that cyclicals will make a comeback and corporate banks should lead the market rally. What happens to consumer names? Where are HUL, Britannia, Page Industries and ITC headed?
I should not be sending a wrong message because I am very clear and that is why I actually said I am long right now because I clearly believe that markets are headed much higher irrespective of what happens in that month or two during the election uncertainty in case we get the other outcome that is the current government does not come to power which as of now does not seem really a possibility. 

So, irrespective of election outcome, the event will be out of the way and the markets are headed much higher because the economy should pick up. It is showing first signs of coming out of that long phase of contraction and slow growth. The interest rate environment is looking benign and therefore there is no reason why the consumers would not be robust. Consumption would be good and consumer stocks would do well. 

We can debate the earnings multiples they trade at. A lot of people are hiding in them as defensives for the last many months. The question would always come where do I want to buy that ITC or a Britannia or a Dabur or a Marico? For an investor, volatility is the best friend. You get a panic, you want to be in defensives, in some of the evergreen names. These are places to be but you have to get your buying levels right because market is an animal which one doesn’t really know the way it goes, particularly in these kind of environments when the situation is clouded and there are uncertainties all over. There will be a few negative days and that is the time to come and buy your Britannia and ITC because if you have them in the portfolio for two, three years, you are going to make huge money. 

These will be absolutely safe places to be in the sense you would not have to live with the problem that one sees with banks and other companies in the sector like steel, cement etc.

NEW DELHI: FMCG shares were trading lower in Wednesday's afternoon session.

Shares of Tata Global Beverages (down 1.82 per cent) , Britannia Industries (down 0.81 per cent) , United Spirits (down 0.75 per cent) , and Procter & Gamble Hygiene & Healthcare (down 0.63 per cent) were the top losers in the index. 

Marico (down 0.54 per cent) , Dabur India (down 0.50 per cent) , Godrej Consumer Products (down 0.44 per cent) and ColgatePalmolive (India) (down 0.10 per cent) too were trading with losses. 

The Nifty FMCG index was trading 0.08 per cent down at 30,408.80 around 12:37 pm. 

Benchmark NSE Nifty50 index was down 17.75 points at 11,514.65 while the BSE Sensex was up 6.09 points at 38,369.56. 

Among the 50 stocks in the Nifty index, 15 were trading in the green, while 35 were in the red. 

Shares of BHEL, Indian Oil Corp, Bank of Baroda, ONGC, NTPC, BEL, SAIL, SBI, Infosys, YES Bank, ITC, Ashok Leyland, Coal India and JSW Steel were among the most traded shares on the NSE.

MUMBAI: Leading biscuit companies are seeing smaller and local players eat into their sales since the new goods and tax regime came into force, and they claim that these companies, mostly unbranded ones, offer higher retail margins and lower price points since they are not GST compliant.

With the Rs 35,000-crore biscuit market the largest category within FMCG, a single percentage drop is as big as sales loss of Rs 350 crore. “Many players are not tax-compliant and have low operating cost which helps give high margins to retailers who push brands mostly in rural areas,” said Mayank Shah, category head, Parle Products. He said they are seeking a tax reduction from 18% for biscuits below Rs 100/kg to 5% bracket.

Britannia, Parle and ITC control nearly 69% of the biscuit market in the country. In fact, the top 15 players including Mondelez, Anmol and Saj Industries put together account for 92% of the segment. While Nielsen data, sourced from officials, suggests 1% share drop for Parle and ITC each over the past two years, Parle said the market researcher doesn’t track regional brands, which are restricted to just one district.

This is in contrast on what most companies expected during the new tax regime in 2017. Analysts too anticipated an increase in market share of organised players over their unorganised rivals as the price differential of products was likely to reduce while making tax evasion incrementally difficult with a significant compliance cost burden.







“Biscuits are a staple and the most basic packaged food products in the country. Rate should be reduced to 12% so that it can be effectively passed through price-cuts, which in turn, will boost consumption and make it level playing field," said Varun Berry, managing director at Britannia Industries, the country's largest biscuit maker.

During last calendar year, the biscuit category grew 12%, slower compared to 14% in 2017. Companies estimate 3,500-4,000 smaller and loose biscuit firms operate in just one region or district, all nibbling away at their sales growth For years, local brands — not just in biscuits but in most segments — have eaten into share from leading consumer product companies, especially in soaps, detergents, hair oil, tea and biscuits, with more than 500 unorganised players operating in these categories.

In segments such as tea, smaller players and loose tea operators control 40% of the market, while in detergents and soaps, hundreds of local companies enter the market at a time when crude oil prices, a key ingredient for detergents, bottom out since that’s the only cost incurred in making the products.

MUMBAI: Patanjali Ayurved disrupted the Indian fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) sector with nature-based products in various categories to challenge the dominance of companies such as Hindustan Unilever (HUL) in the past three-four years. 

That has forced rivals, especially the multinationals, to retool their portfolios to introduce matching products at similar price points to try and regain their market ranking, analysts said. This seems to be paying off, they said.

The homegrown upstart has been most successful in staples such as ghee, flour, ayurvedic health supplements, toothpaste, edible oil and condiments but less so in noodles, biscuits, personal care, chocolates and juices.

Its rapid growth posed a threat to mainstream FMCG companies by renewing the natural/herbal/ayurvedic theme and compelling FMCG companies to tweak their range. For instance, HUL’s personal care products faced headwinds, prompting the company to relaunch its Ayush brand and acquire ayurvedic hair oil brand Indulekha. Having sustained similar damage in the oral care segment, Colgate-Palmolive launched its own herbal toothpaste.




The Patanjali effect on Colgate-Palmolive is waning, possibly due to distribution and supply chain issues apart from the fading novelty of its products, according to JPMorgan’s report this month on the FMCG sector by Latika Chopra and Sushruta Mishra.

While hurting FMCG companies in the short term, Patanjali predominantly gained market share in commoditised categories made up of unorganised players.


‘COMPANY CAN TROUBLE UNORGANISED PLAYERS’
Competitive intensity has faded in the organised end since Patanjali’s products no longer have the unique selling proposition (USP) of being natural with other brands having entered the market at similar or lower price points, experts said.

“The threat has receded but it is more of a case of Patanjali having lost the plot,” said Milind Sarwate, former CFO of Marico and now an independent director on several boards. “They tried too many things. They have not looked at their growing in scale at the back end. They succeeded in demand creation but not in demand fulfilment. They fell short of the institutional strength to sustain the rising volume. Their threat is definitely lower because they had internal issues — supply not being on time, trade not happy with them.”

Patanjali is diversifying into new categories such as garments and education. It’s also in the fray to acquire Ruchi Soya, a large player in the commoditised industry of solvent extraction or edible oils.

Analysts say that the company is likely to pose more of a threat to the unorganised sector going forward.

“Even if Patanjali is able to overcome its recent issues on quality and supply chain, we expect it to gain market share in these commoditised categories at the expense of unorganised players, and not pose a major threat to the listed F&B companies playing in non-commoditised categories,” said the food and beverage report released by Systematix Investments earlier this month. Still, Patanjali retains the ability to create further disruption, said Sarwate.

“Patanjali cannot be ignored by the market leaders — they are capable of a surprise,” he said. “I expect them to do something dramatic like giving 30% discount on their products or so.”

The JPMorgan report says there is a downside risk for Dabur’s growth prospects due to the overlap of categories with Patanjali such as chyawanprash, honey, hair oil and toothpaste.

Based on ETIG data, Nestle and Britannia have outperformed on the ground as well as on the bourses, despite competition from Patanjali. Dabur also has managed to keep improving its performance amid competitive intensity.

HUL’s market share in soaps has been resilient even after the entry of Patanjali, according to the latest report by Reliance Securities.

Smart money always gets in earlier and the local guy acts after the news, said Basant 
   
   
   Maheshwari, Co-founder & Partner, Basant Maheshwari Wealth Advisers, in an interview with ETNOW.Edited excerpts:

Bank Nifty is at a record high. Nifty is inching towards a life high. Would you call it a pre-election run-up or the beginning of a fresh run?
From a broad perspective, I will call it a post-election rally that is happening pre-election. Smart money is getting in. Once the election results are out and if this government comes back, the retailers would get in at whatever be the Nifty level at that point and whatever has been now would normally be sold to the retailers. This is an old story. Smart money always gets in earlier and the local guy acts after the news. We have always learnt this ever since we came into the market that buy at rumour and sell on news. That is what is happening right now.


We saw a similar factor at play in 2004 when smart money bought ahead of the elections but then the election verdict was not favourable.
The markets did come down at that time but if you remember there was this CPI(M) leader who suddenly said bhaar mein jai share bazaar (to hell with the share market) and that spooked the market at that time. For some people, share bazaar is life and death. I do not think any such situation would happen. But even if it does, it was just a knee-jerk reaction. What happened in 2004 was once the markets fell, they recovered in no time and CY2004 still gave a positive return. People say there is a huge risk of buying when there is no clarity. But I think there is a huge risk of buying when there is clarity. 

Six months back – there was the IL&FS issue and all the NBFCs were written off. Of course, 90% of them would never ever come back to the same price but the best one is ready to take out its all-time high. You have to buy looking at the fundamentals but we learnt an interesting lesson last year that fundamentals is not everything. There has to be something else which dictates why you buy and sell shares. It is a mix and match of everything but personally for our clients, for ourselves, we are more than fully invested and aggressively positioned.


All those naysayers on banks missed out in buying the Axis even Yes Bank. Do you think there is still money to be made in banks? Would the rally spread outside ICICI Bank, HDFC Bank, Yes Bank to some degree and Axis? Would it spread to PSBs or is it going to be a very restrictive rally?
If you have a one-year view, we do not own it. It is not a recommendation. Axis and ICICI will outperform HDFC Bank but if you have a five-year view and you want to go back to sleep and don’t want to wake up each night thinking what is going to happen to the Nasdaq, to the Dow, to the SGX Nifty, HDFC Bank still remains a no-brainer. Again, it is not our recommendation.

Why I talk about one-year and five-year view is because ICICI and Axis are playing a valuation catch-up. It is not a growth catch-up. With the new management coming in, for Rs 2-3-4 lakh-crore asset book, how much money can one siphon off? That has already been taken care of by the market. I am talking about ICICI right now. Axis has the best of brains coming from an insurance company. He is going to try and change the bank but then this is not a five-year bet in my view. We do not own it and so I can talk about it. It is a one-year view, a six-month or maybe a nine-month view. But that is for people who want to buy and sell. Do buy and sell but if you want to still go back to sleep peacefully, HDFC Bank is there for you. 

Remember HDFC Bank did a QIP at Rs 2,200 last year and those QIP guys are still to see the price and HDFC is not another company in India which will do a QIP and never come back. They also noted that in three years they have to do another offering. So those guys have to make money and the management will ensure that the guys who bought it at Rs 2,200 last year would make money because they have to do this repetitively to make up the gap between the ROE and growth. So, HDFC Bank is also fine. All these big private banks are fine but if you want to be cute and start playing the PSU banks, that would be a very dangerous thing to do.


What has kept you away from Axis and ICICI Bank?
We were already holding the companies which we own and they were doing very well. In some cases, you do not want to sell a company just because you want to buy something else. If you have fresh cash, you go and buy it but normally you do not want to do all that tinkering unnecessarily. Also, we do not take very small positions, we normally take 10%, 15% of our portfolios. So, maybe we missed it, but we do not want to tinker around because the ones which we have, have also done quite well from the lows.


If I have to capture a 15-20% growth for next three years, which is that expensive consumer dominated stock I should go for? Or should I rather buy a cyclical/corporate bank or a beaten down NBFC where I will still get 15-18% growth at half the valuation?

About five years back, I had umpteen number of people calling and saying Corporation Bank lelo, iska dividend yield dekh lo, Dena Bank lelo iska dividend yield dekh lo (Buy Corporation Bank, Dena Bank. Look at their dividend yield). Suddenly we realised what a mess we are in. The point is consistency is the single most important factor in stock analysis and we have understood that. Sometimes you have to pay a lot of money, sometimes you pay little money to understand that. If you are sure about it, 15-18% is not good enough for a 40 PE, it has to be above or around 25%. If you are sure of 25% growth for the next 10 years or like seven years at least, not five, not three, I would pay 40-50 trailing to buy a 25% growing company for the next five, seven years. 

But if the growth is in the 15-18% range, you go and buy an Asian Paints or anything else. It is a little difficult to actually put your finger on the pie but then what decides that PE is not just growth, it is the sustainability of that growth, the ability of the company to handle its situation and still deliver the growth like out of the NBFC space where 60-80% of the companies were almost wiped off their feet last October. But still there was one company which delivered stellar results. So, why not buy more of that because once the competition weakens the market share shifting process becomes a lot more easier. 

All opinions do not make money and we have understood that we might have 200 different opinions but then you have to go and act on that. Right now, everybody has an opinion but nobody wants to act on that opinion. They are just waiting for something to happen and that something would be 11,700 taken out around the election time. That is where the new gush of money is going to come in. 

That is where everybody would find something good to talk about and something good to buy in this market, till that gets taken out, we will have our own fear about whether to buy or not to buy.


How did you insulate yourself in this entire NBFC/HFC slowdown? You have owned HFC stocks in the past. Is this an opportunity to shift your portfolio to better quality NBFCs or HFCs or are you thinking twice about where the sector is headed?
We do not own any HFC right now. We got fed up and dumped it sometime back and we bought a great consumer company which should grow 25% for the next five, seven, eight years. We just own one NBFC and it is not a recommendation again, everybody knows it. It is Bajaj Finance and we are more than fully invested into that as on the allocation perspective and they should do fine. That is about it. 

We make mistakes in life and my mistake was balance sheet is not enough so it is like unless the kanya daan happens, the baratis would not get the food to eat. The kanya daan did not happen with HFC and we got no food to eat. After two years, with stock doubling, we almost sold when it fell 30-40% from the top but that is how life is. We learn something new in life and then you move on. 


What would you buy if you had extra cash right now? Would it be cyclicals?
I do not think we should be buying cyclicals because nothing changes. It is the same country, same politicians, same politics, same policies and sometimes I get fearful of the way this country is going to polls. It seems the politicians have formed a group to auction the entire country! Somebody says I will give you Rs 6,000, somebody says I will give you Rs 1,500. People forget it is our money. The country cannot be auctioned for politics and then the Election Commission will charge somebody who distributes Rs 500 and one liquor bottle saying this is bribing. 

Somebody should file a PIL in the Supreme Court saying that this kind of pre-election dole-out should be completely banned from this country because if this happens, you will not have Bangladeshis and Burmese people coming to India. You will have Indians going into Burma and Bangladesh. I am very fearful of what politics is going to turn right now. So you better be in the best consumer and financial services names. Make 2% less, but at least protect the Rs 100 that you had brought to the market.


 A lot of companies are deleveraging and some amount of consolidation is on. What would be the outcome going forward?
First you goof up and then you go and deleverage. Look what happened to Jet. First they goofed up and then nobody wanted 200 pilots and 5,000 airhostesses going around airports protesting just before an election and so Jet was actually asked to extend its life. A company like Jet is not a recommendation. It has just been put on a ventilator. When your operating profit is less than the interest cost that you have to pay, the best you can do is survive. Even if you can survive. where is the cash flow to repay the debt? 

A lot of telecom companies are under this situation right now. Unless the big daddy of them all actually increases prices, it is like stopping the oxygen flow from your peer group. In the telecom sector, a couple of companies are standing on the brink. This deleveraging is not happening just because suddenly they have decided to let us reward the minority. It is happening out of compulsion and deleveraging happening out of compulsion is never a great thing for shareholders. Deleveraging when it happens on a discretionary basis is great because normally the valuation of a company goes up multi-fold when it starts repaying debt out of cash flow. But if you repay debt by selling off your assets, it is something different.


Would you say the same about DLF also? After the Rs 3,000-crore QIP, they are almost debt free now?
Not DLF. No recommendation again. But they do not have this problem of getting into bankruptcy. It is a different story. I am talking about the telecom companies, the airline companies where one doesn’t know how far this deleveraging is going to take them. The deleveraging only guarantees an extension of the old life. Investor should be very mindful of what they are doing right now because as Rs 200 stocks go to Rs 250, you think something has changed. I have got nothing against these companies -- neither short nor long. 


Which are some stocks which you do not own but you would like to own? If there is a crash, where will you be a buyer?
We do not own it and it is not a recommendation but Axis and ICICI are good. Please do not buy just because I am saying it. Do your own research. May be in the consumer space, something which we do not own and something which you have liked for a while -- Britannia looks okay. Companies like these are okay but again not a recommendation for the viewers. 


Those who are sitting on cash, if they find value they should put money to work even though election it could have short-term implications of 5%, 10%, 15% in midcap stocks. That should not stop you from investing.
Absolutely. It is much much easier to buy a stock and see it go down 30% than to buy a stock 10% above the price at which you first saw it. If you missed a certain stock, what are you going to do? You are going to buy the B or the C or the D names of that sector and that is what investors should not be doing. 

If you are okay buying something at 10% above after elections, then you should wait. But if you missed stock A, and then bought B or C or D, that is where the problem starts. It is okay to buy when the stock fell 10%. Finally, it is a stock market and not a fixed deposit which is going to hit an all-time high every second. You just buy it. If it falls, it falls. That’s about it.

NEW DELHI: Strong gains in banking, financial and IT stocks gave a fillip to the Indian equity market on Thursday as positive signals from the ongoing US-China trade talks fuelled investor risk appetite.

Reports that China has made some unprecedented proposals in trade talks with the US to overcome the remaining obstacles to a deal lifted investor confidence. Moreover, unabated FPI flows kept the sentiment high. Data suggests FPIs have pumped Rs 29,089 crore into domestic equities so far in March. 

Sensex surged 413 points, or 1.08 per cent, to close at 38,545, with 23 stocks ending in the green, seven in the red. One remained unchanged. Nifty jumped 125 points, or 1.09 per cent, to 11,570, with 37 stocks up and 13 down.

BSE Midcap and Smallcap indices closed higher by 1.06 per cent and 0.95 per cent, respectively. 


Here’s a look at the highlights of Thursday's session:

Infosys buys 75% in ABN AMRO BankThe IT major said it would acquire a 75 per cent stake in Stater NV, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Netherlands’ third largest lender ABN AMRO. The acquisition, the company said, would boost operational efficiencies and enhance its strategy to help clients navigate their digital transformation. The stock settled 1.30 per cent higher at Rs 738. 


DHFL shares surge 10%Shares of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) closed 9.53 per cent higher at Rs 149.40 after media reports suggested that Piramal Enterprises and Baring Private Equity (PE) are in talks to acquire a majority stake in the company. 


BoB jumps on govt capital infusionShares of Bank of Baroda (BoB) closed 6.62 per cent higher at Rs 129.60 after the government said it would infuse Rs 5,042 crore in the bank ahead of its merger of Dena Bank and Vijaya Bank on April 1. Separately, an ET report suggested that the bank is set to raise up to $1 billion by selling bonds overseas to solidify its capital position. 


Sheela Foam OFS subscribed 5.23 timesThe offer for sale (OFS) by Sheela Foam received strong response from retail investors and was subscribed 5.23 times on Day 2. The issue received retail bids for 27,26,373 shares, which was 5.23 times the total size of 5,20,942 shares. The portion for the retail category was fixed at 10 per cent.


Titan's m-cap tops Rs 1 lakh cr markThe market capitalisation of Titan jumped to Rs 1,00,674.95 crore as the stock touched its all-time high of Rs 1,135. It closed the day 1.77 per cent higher at Rs 1,134.


Rs 1.52 lakh cr wealth created in a dayThursday's market rally made investors richer by Rs 1.52 lakh crore as the overall market-capitalisation of BSE-listed firms jumped to Rs 1,49,83,159.64 crore from Rs 1,48,30,498.41 crore a day earlier. 


PFC completes REC buyState-owned Power Finance Corporation completed the acquisition of majority stake in REC by paying Rs 14,500 crore to the government, PTI reported. The transaction will help the government meet its disinvestment target of Rs 80,000 crore for this financial year. Shares of PFC closed 0.13 per cent down at Rs 117.55, while those of REC closed flat at Rs 149.30.


84 stocks show potential to riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 84 counters on BSE, indicating that these stocks may see upsides in the coming sessions. Among the stocks that showed bullish crossovers were Delta Corp, Oil India, ICICI Prudential Life Insurance, Phillips Carbon Black, United Bank of India and Indian Bank. On the other hand, 74 stocks, including Tata Power, Exide Industries, HPCL, Reliance Naval, Aster DM Healthcare, Bajaj Finserv, Britannia Industries and SRF, saw bearish crossovers. 


UCO Bank, Indian Bank above 200 DMAsUnited Bank, UCO Bank, Radico Khaitan, Panacea Biotec, Indian Bank and Weizmann Forex were among the stocks that traded above their 200 DMAs. On the flip side, Mindtree, Jet Airways, ONGC, Ashoka Buildcon, Raymond and Welspun India were among the stocks that traded below their 200 DMAs.

NEW DELHI: Financial year 2018-19 turned out to be the best in four for domestic equities, despite several headwinds and a crippling bear hug midway through the year.

Sensex wrapped up the financial year with 17 per cent gains to close at 38,672 on Friday, up 127 points, or 0.33 per cent, for the day, while Nifty settled 54 points, or 0.47 per cent, higher at 11,623.

While positive signals from US-China trade talks kept the mood upbeat, sustained FPI inflow and hopes of a rate cut by RBI pushed investors to build fresh positions. 


Here we walk you through the ket highlights of Friday's session:

Equity investors make Rs 9L cr in FY19The domestic equity market ended the best financial year in four on Friday, with Sensex logging 17 per cent gain. Equity investors got richer by around Rs 9 lakh crore for the year, as total market-cap of BSE-listed stocks rose from around Rs 142 lakh crore to Rs 151 lakh crore. The 30-share index last posted a better show in FY15, when it had risen 24.89 per cent. 


Spurt in OIVodafone Idea, with a change of 129.62 per cent, led the pack of stocks that witnessed biggest spurt in open interest (OI) on NSE. It was followed by IDBI Bank (59.75 per cent), SRF (44.07 per cent), Reliance Power (32.86 per cent) and GAIL (27.63 per cent). 


Vodafone Idea jumps 4%Extending the gains into the second consecutive session, shares of Vodafone Idea closed 3.71 per cent higher at Rs 18.15. The stock saw traction after reports that the company was pushing for an equal stake in optic fibre venture with Airtel.


Rs 1.25 lakh cr wealth created in a dayFriday’s gains in the market made investors richer by Rs 1.25 lakh crore as overall market capitalisation of BSE-listed firm rose to Rs 1,51,08,711 crore from Rs 1,49,83,159 crore on Thursday. In the last two sessions, the overall m-cap has jumped by Rs 2.78 lakh crore. 


RVNL IPO subscribed 8% on Day 1The initial public offer (IPO) of Rail Vikas Nigam (RVNL) was subscribed 8 per cent on Day 1 of the bidding process. Data on the NSE website available till 4:30 pm on Friday showed the IPO had received bids for 2,10,38,160 shares against the total issue size of 25,34,57,280. 


MSTC makes tepid debutShares of Kolkata-headquartered MSTC made a tepid debut, as the scrip got listed at Rs 111 on BSE, a 7.5 per cent discount to the issue price of Rs 120. The scrip closed at Rs 114.20, down 4.83 per cent from issue price.


Britannia replaces HPCL in Nifty50Shares of Britannia Industries slipped 0.19 per cent even as the company replaced Hindustan Petroleum Corporation in Nifty50. HPCL shares settled 3.83 per cent higher at Rs 283.


WABCO India jumps 5%Shares of WABCO India jumped 4.71 per cent to close at Rs 6,662 as the company entered a definitive merger agreement with ZF Friedrichshafen AG, a privately-held global leader in driveline and chassis technologies. 


PNB sells stake in PNB HousingPunjab National Bank (PNB) in a BSE filing said it will sell its stake in PNB Housing Finance to General Atlantic and Varde Partners for Rs 1,851 crore. Varde Partners and General Atlantic will buy 1.09 crore shares each at Rs 850 per share, valuing the purchase at Rs 925.80 crore each. The PNB stock closed with a nominal gain of 0.05 per cent at Rs 95.40, while PNB Housing Finance rose 4.36 per cent to Rs 865 on BSE. 


Jet misses loan payment to HSBCJet Airways missed a $109 million loan repayment due to HSBC Bank this week, Bloomberg reported. The money was due on March 28 and was part of a two-tranche facility totalling $140 million that the company took from HSBC in 2014. Jet shares closed flat at Rs 269.35.


128 stocks signal riseMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bullish crossovers on 128 counters on BSE, signalling potential rise in the coming sessions. Among the stocks were Lakshmi Vilas Bank, Adani Enterprises, Central Bank of India, India Cements, United Breweries and Tata Power. On the other hand, SBI Life Insurance, Bombay Dyeing, Escorts and Sunteck Realty were among 65 stocks that showed bearish crossovers on BSE.

Meanwhile, shares of Hindustan Petroleum Corporation were trading 2.82 per cent higher at Rs 280.75 on BSE.

Six stocks, Bajaj Holdings & Investment, Divi's Laboratories, HDFC Asset Management Company, Hindustan Petroleum Corporation, Page Industries and United Breweries will be included in the Nifty Next50.

The shares of Britannia Industries closed 0.19 per cent lower Rs 3081.95 while that of HPCL closed 3.83 per cent higher at Rs 283.50 on BSE.

NEW DELHI: Strong rollovers data and easing of volatility ahead of the elections suggest the market is complacent about the poll outcome but a weakening global economy remains a worry. Let’s check out what may move market all through Friday:


TRADE SETUP


Singapore trading sets stage for negative startNifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 23.50 points, or 0.20 per cent, lower at 11,646.50, indicating a negative start for the Nifty50.



Tech view: Nifty forms long bullish candleThursday was the third day in a row when the Nifty50 formed higher high and higher low, suggesting that the support was shifting higher. Analysts said the 11,500 level may act as an immediate support for the index. Resistance, they said, could be seen in the 11,600-660 range.



Market-wide rollovers at 81%Nifty futures rollovers stood at 67 per cent against 65 per cent rollovers seen in the last three series. Market-wide rollovers stood at 81 per cent. "We expect Nifty to hit levels of 11,800 in April series," said Edelweiss Securities.



FPIs buy Rs 3,595 crore worth of equitiesForeign portfolio investors (FPIs) bought Rs 3,595 crore worth of domestic stocks on Thursday, data available with NSE suggested. DIIs were net sellers to the tune of Rs 2,080 crore, data suggested.



Asian stocks inch up on US-China talksAsian shares posted narrow gains on Friday on revived hopes of progress in US-China trade talks, while global bond yields moved higher after a prolonged slide on worries about the economic outlook. MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan edged up 0.1 per cent while Japan's Nikkei rose 1 per cent.



US stocks settle higherUS stocks climbed on Thursday as Treasury yields rose off 15-month lows, with investors optimistic about the latest round of US-China trade talks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 91.87 points, or 0.36 per cent, to 25,717.46, the S&P500 index gained 10.07 points, or 0.36 per cent, to 2,815.44 and the Nasdaq Composite index added 25.79 points, or 0.34 percent, to 7,669.17.



MSTC to make market debut todayThe state-owned MSTC's initial share sale, whose IPO was extended till March 20, will list on Friday. The issue was eventually subscribed 1.46 times.



Britannia to enter elite Nifty50 clubBritannia Industries will replace Hindustan Petroleum Corporation in the Nifty50 today. Six stocks, Bajaj Holdings & Investment, Divi's Laboratories, HDFC Asset Management Company, Hindustan Petroleum Corporation, Page Industries and United Breweries will be included in the Nifty Next50.



Rail Vikas Nigam IPO to kick off todayMiniratna Rail Vikas Nigam (RVNL), which received Sebi’s nod for IPO in May last year, is finally coming out with its offer on Friday. The company has IRCON International as listed peer, which debuted in September last year and is quoting at a 15 per cent discount to issue price. Analysts said investors with a long-term horizon may subscribe to the issue.



Oil prices up in early tradeOil prices rose on Friday, pushed up by ongoing supply cuts led by producer club OPEC and US sanctions against Iran and Venezuela, which have given crude markets the biggest first quarter price push since 2009. US WTI futures were at $59.54 per barrel, up 24 cents, or 0.4 per cent


MONEY MARKETS


Rupee down: The rupee slumped 42 paise to end at 69.30 against the US dollar Thursday, its second straight session of decline, in line with other Asian currencies amid strengthening of the greenback. 



10-yr bond yields down: India 10-year bonds' yields fell 0.01% to 7.33% on Wednesday from 7.34% over the previous trading session, according to RBI data.



Call rate: The overnight call money rate weighted average was 6.15% on Wednesday, according to RBI data. It moved in a range of 4.80-6.30%. 


TOP VIDEO
The Minimum income scheme is about better targetting, empowering people: Raghuram Rajan




TOP QUOTE

'We are in multiple bubbles, hide in precious metals'



MACROS


Sebi turns heat on debt MFs’ loan deals with promotersThe Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi) is conducting a detailed probe into complex structures that debt mutual funds have entered into for loans to promoter group firms in recent years. Sebi has asked mutual fund trustees to review the exposure and risk management practices of such debt schemes and submit the findings by March 31.



Govt throws Rs 21,428 cr lifeline to five PSBsFive state-owned banks, including PNB, Bank of Baroda and Union Bank, Thursday received shareholders' approval for capital infusion to the tune of Rs 21,428 crore in lieu of preferential allotment of shares to the government. This capital infusion is for the current fiscal ending March 31, 2019. The Indian Overseas Bank and Central Bank were the other two recipients.



Rural consumer demand cools on poll heat, farm stressConsumer demand for daily groceries, apparel, smartphones and electronics, especially in rural markets, has eased since January due to preelection uncertainty, tighter liquidity and depressed farm incomes following a patchy monsoon. Rural consumption, which accounts for about a third of the market, saw a revival with double-digit growth in the past two years, outpacing the rate of expansion in cities.



US-China talks could drag for monthsUS trade talks with China could stretch for “months”, Donald Trump’s top economic adviser said on Thursday, offering the latest indication of a slowdown in the negotiations to end the commercial conflict between the world’s two most powerful economies. China has made unprecedented proposals in talks with the United States on a range of issues including forced technology transfer as the two sides work to overcome remaining obstacles to a deal to end their protracted trade war.



Last chance for May's Brexit DealBritish Prime Minister Theresa May hopes to bring her twice-defeated Brexit deal back to parliament for another vote. To get it through she will need to win over at least 75 lawmakers. At least 20 Conservative lawmakers have indicated since March 12 that they would now support her deal, mainly due to fears the alternative could be a closer relationship with the European Union or not leaving at all.



Third-party motor insurance rates unchanged for new fiscalIn a relief for motor insurance holders, annual premium rates increase for third party motor insurance policies have been put on hold for the next financial year for now. Insurance regulator Irdai said that insurers will continue to charge the rates currently being charged for Motor Third Party Liability Insurance Cover from April 1, 2019 until further orders.

Global funds are making a beeline for India big time. Their growing interest, along with expectations of Narendra Modi taking power again and forecast of plentiful rains ahead, gave the bulls enough will power to stay in-charge for the sixth straight week on Dalal Street. 

The Sensex rose 1.33 per cent, or 508 points, to 38,673 for the week to March 30. NSE's Nifty jumped 1.46 per cent, or 167 points, to 11,624. 

The finance ministry said liquidity in the economy is comfortable and will improve further with the central bank’s move to infuse Rs 35,000 crore through the rupee-dollar swap auction. That was good enough to stoke investment appetite.

“Hopes of a stable government took the Sensex higher by almost 8 per cent this month. Buying has been mainly led by FIIs who have put in around Rs 45,000 core into domestic markets. We believe that any rate cuts in developed markets such as the US or Europe may result in steady inflows for emerging markets (EMs),” said Hemang Jani, Head-Advisory, Sharekhan by BNP Paribas. 

All eyes are on national elections starting next month, which will keep domestic markets volatile in the short term. The results are due on May 23. 

In the long term, corporate earnings growth and revival in private capex remain crucial for further market upside, say experts.

How did major stocks and sectors play up the whole week? There we go.


The IPO update


Rail Vikas Nigam: The initial public offer (IPO) of state-owned Rail Vikas Nigam got subscribed 9 per cent on the first day of the bidding on Friday. The Rs 481-crore offering received bids for 2,19,01,620 shares against the total issue size of 25,34,57,280, NSE data showed.


MSTC: State-owned MSTC made a weak market debut on Friday and settled over 5 per cent down compared with the issue price of Rs 120 per share. The stock opened the day at Rs 111, down 7.5 per cent against the issue price on the BSE. Intra-day, it touched a high of Rs 116.55 and a low of Rs 110.05. However, it settle the day at Rs 114.20, 4.83 per cent lower.


Top Nifty movers
With a rally of 18 per cent, Indiabulls Housing Finance emerged as the leader of the Nifty pack. It was followed by YES Bank (up 8.91 per cent), State Bank of India (up 7.62 per cent), Bajaj Finance (up 6.64 per cent) and HCL Technologies (up 6.11 per cent). 
On the other hand, Eicher Motors, Wipro, Hero MotoCorp, Hindalco, Tech Mahindra and Bajaj Auto slipped 1.30-4.19 per cent.


Jet Airways flies higher
Shares of Jet Airways rallied nearly 19 per cent after founder Naresh Goyal on Monday quit as a board member, with the lenders taking control and deciding to infuse Rs 1,500 crore immediately into the ailing airline. The scrip settled the week at Rs 268.80 against Rs 226.10 on March 22.


DHFL takes spotlight
Dewan Housing Finance Corporation Ltd (DHFL) soared over 12 per cent during the week amid reports that Piramal Group and Baring Private Equity (PE) are in talks to acquire a majority stake in the company. The scrip advanced 12.34 per cent to Rs 150.30 during the week.


Britannia replaces HPCL on Nifty
FMCG firm Britannia Industries replaced OMC major Hindustan Petroleum Corporation on the Nifty50 on Friday. The stock closed 0.19 per cent down at Rs 3,081.95 on March 29 while HPCL settled 3.83 per cent up at Rs 283.50.


WABCO India drives up
Shares of WABCO India rallied nearly 5 per cent on Friday after the company clinched a definitive merger deal with ZF Friedrichshafen AG, a privately-held global leader in driveline and chassis technologies.


Stocks @ new all-time highs
As many as 25 stocks of the BSE500 index hit their fresh record highs during the week. The list included stocks such as ICICI Lombard General Insurance, Varun Beverages, RBL Bank, Future Lifestyle, Muthoot Finance, Ipca Labs, PI Industries, UPL, ICICI Bank, SKF India, Pidilite Industries, Torrent Pharma and Merck.


The sectoral scene
Among BSE sectoral indices, Consumer Durables rallied the most -- 3.09 per cent -- for the week under review. It was followed by Oil & Gas (up 3.08 per cent), Bankex (up 2.99 per cent), Metal (up 1.82 per cent) and Power (1.68 per cent). BSE Telecom (down 0.42 per cent) was the only loser.


Titan m-cap tops Rs 1 lakh cr 
The market capitalisation (m-cap) of Titan surpassed Rs 1 lakh crore for the first time ever. With a rally of over 3.50 per cent, m-cap of the company jumped to Rs 1,00,985.70 crore on Friday, from Rs 98,073.70 on March 22. Before closing 0.69 per cent up at Rs 1,137.50, the scrip scaled its all-time high of Rs 1,146 on Friday.

NEW DELHI: Nifty futures on the Singapore Exchange were trading 16 points, or 0.14 per cent, higher at 11,701, indicating a positive start for the Nifty50. Here are a few stocks which may buzz the most in today’s session: 

IB Housing Finance, LVB: The boards of Lakshmi Vilas Bank (LVB) and Indiabulls Housing Finance are set to meet this week to consider a proposal to merge the old private sector bank with the home finance company.


Maruti Suzuki: The country’s largest car maker cut vehicle production by around 21 per cent across its factories in March due to subdued demand. The auto major produced a total of 1,36,201 units in March, it said in a regulatory filing.


Titan Company: The jewellery maker is targeting an overall 20 per cent growth in FY20 despite the muted outlook for the economy. The March quarter performance was on expected lines and jewellery division grew by just over 22 per cent in FY 19, the company said.


Axis Bank: The lender has terminated more than 50 mid-level managers as it restructures its business and cuts cost under a new chief executive. As executive vice-presidents and vice-presidents, the affected officials led various supervisory functions in corporate and retail banking.


JSW Steel: India's biggest maker of the alloy is set to raise $500 million by selling dollar bonds, ending a year-long wait for garnering debt funds overseas.


GMR Infra: GMR Airports, a stepdown subsidiary of infrastructure conglomerate GMR Infrastructure, raised $300 million through a bond issue in the international market to part fund an expansion plan to nearly triple passenger handling capacity at Hyderabad International Airport.


Cipla: Pharma major Cipla said it has received an establishment inspection report (EIR) from the US health regulator after inspection of its Goa facility.


PVR: The companyhas signed deals with CJ 4DPLEX, the world's leading cinema technology company, and D-BOX Technologies, a world leader in immersive motion entertainment experiences, to open 10 ScreenX theatres and install 400 D-BOX seats across 9 cinemas in India.


Britannia Industries: Food company Britannia Industries said it has raised Rs 500 crore through issuance of commercial paper.


Magma Fincorp: The NBFC is eyeing an asset growth of around Rs 3,000 crore in the 2019-20 fiscal, a top official of the company said on Thursday.


Hindustan Copper: The state-owned firm said provisional copper ore production for the 2018-19 fiscal stood at 41.22 lakh tonnes, 12 per cent higher than that of last year.


Vedanta: Moody's Investors Service has assigned B2 rating to Vedanta's proposed senior unsecured notes and said the outlook was negative.

• Elara Capital has reiterated its buy rating on Parag Milk Foods with a target price of ₹366. The brokerage expect 18% sales growth in FY19-21, led by high double digit growth in value added dairy (VAD) and distribution expansion in the north and east regions. The stock is currently trading at PE of 15 times and EV/EBITDA of 8 times its FY20 estimated earnings. 

• Sharekhan has upgraded its rating on Federal Bank to buy with a revised target price of ₹110. Bank’s efforts to diversify its income source by investments in related businesses, adding new streams to fee and other income are bearing fruits, albeit slowly, said the brokerage. The stock is currently trades at 1.2 times its FY 2021 estimated book value, which is attractive, according to Sharekhan. 

• Motilal Oswal has maintained its buy rating on Amara Raja Batteries with a price target of ₹861. While the industry structure remains largely duopoly, the company has emerged as a formidable challenger to leader EXIDE, with a market leadership in telecom and UPS segments, and a fast gaining share in autos, said the brokerage. 

• SBICAP Securities recommend hold rating on Dabur with a target price of ₹500. We like Dabur as diversification not only makes it safe and less vulnerable to sudden competitive, regulatory, inflationary and growth issues in any category but also ensures stable growth, said the brokerage.

• Reliance Securities has recommended buy rating on Maruti Suzuki with target price of ₹7,750, valuing the stock at 21 times FY21 estimated EPS. Maruti has been banking on success of its new launches and the brokerage expects increase in first time buyers from healthy rural demand post election amid government’s rural focus.

Forecast of a below-normal monsoon this year by Skymet Weather Services could reverse the positive consumption outlook for the next two quarters and estimates may have to be lowered, consumer goods and auto companies said.

“Weak monsoons will impact the India consumption story,” Britannia managing director Varun Berry said. “A setback to the agricultural economy will certainly impact disposable incomes of the 100 million farmers in the country. We hope Skymet has got it wrong this time.”

Rural markets contribute 25% of revenue for the maker of Good Day and Nutrichoice biscuits and Britannia cheese.

“A below-normal monsoon could impact discretionary spending and we expect some consumption stress in May and June if that happens,” Dabur India chief executive Sunil Duggal said. Rural India accounts for close to half of Dabur’s domestic sales.

In the auto sector, a below-normal monsoon would compound the problem of passenger vehicle and two-wheeler sales growth that would be in lower single digits, companies said. The hinterland and rural areas have made up for falling sales in the major metropolitan cities and any impact on these areas may mean a further lowering of growth rates in the current financial year.

“We have forecast growth of 6-8% for passenger vehicles and two-wheelers due to pre-buying ahead of BSVI (emission standards). We may have to revise it downwards in case of a weak monsoon,” said Subrata Ray, senior group vice president at rating company ICRA.

Skymet said on Wednesday that it expects the monsoon to be ‘below normal’ at 93% of the long-period average of 887 mm for the four-month period from June to September. Normal rainfall would be 96-104% of the long-period average.


Hyundai Motor India national sales head Vikas Jain said that while a healthy monsoon is critical for good growth in rural areas, the spread of rainfall across the country is also important.

“If the monsoon is below normal, car buying takes second priority. I think need-based buying will continue. However, it is the discretionary purchases which will be hit due to weak rains,” Jain said.

N Raja, deputy MD at Toyota Kirloskar, said a below-normal monsoon may impact the festive season this year.

“We were forecasting 3-4% growth in FY20 on the optimistic side, but if the fears of a weak monsoon come true, we will be happy to match FY19 sales,” said Raja.

According to analysts, macroeconomic headwinds such as slower GDP growth, soft consumer price indices and prolonged winters have already impacted the consumption of summer products.

“If the monsoon is below normal, it will hurt an already stressed agrarian economy,” said Anil Chugh, president (consumer ca6re) at Wipro Consumer Care and Lighting, the maker of Santoor soap. “However, Skymet is slightly early in its forecasting and we will wait and watch.”

For Wipro, the rural markets account for 30-35% of annual sales.

An ITC spokesperson said: “The currently buoyant rural demand would naturally be impacted if subnormal monsoon results in lower productivity of the rain-dependant kharif crops. But actual productivity depends on distribution of rainfall during the growing season.”

She added that since farm incomes are supplemented by a number of other sources in the rural economy such as livestock, the company is optimistic, but will keep a close watch on the situation.

Some were of the view that rural areas are no longer vulnerable to weak monsoons.

According to Rajan Wadhera, president for the automotive sector at Mahindra & Mahindra, while the rural economy was previously largely dependent on agri-business, now with other sources of income generation in the hinterland, the impact of a weak monsoon has eased.

NEW DELHI: A strong across-the-board selling, triggered by a sharp rise in crude oil prices and a drop in the rupee made equity benchmark Sensex suffer its biggest fall of Calendar 2019 in absolute terms on Monday.

"The market fell on worries of a sharp rise in crude oil prices. The US is soon likely to ask all importers of Iranian oil to end their purchases or face sanctions," said Pankaj Pandey, Head Research at ICICI Securities. India being the world’s third biggest oil importer, elevated oil prices distort its fiscal maths, widen current account deficit, weaken its currency and stoke inflation.

A 495 points, or 1.26 per cent, fall dragged Sensex to 38,645, while Nifty finished at 11,594, down 158 points or 1.35 per cent.


Let's take a look at the top highlights of Monday's session:

Nearly Rs 2 lakh crore wiped outThe selloff dragged the overall market capitalisation of BSE-listed firms to Rs 1,51,58,835.28 crore from Rs 1,53,53,416.71 crore on Thursday, making equity investors poorer by Rs 1.94 lakh crore.


176 stocks hit lower circuitsAs many as 176 stocks, including Reliance Communications, 8K Miles Software Services, ARSS Infrastructure Projects, Delta Magnets and Darshan Orna, hit lower circuits on BSE. Jaiprakash Power Ventures, Salora International and Jaypee Infratech were among the 139 stocks that hit upper circuits.


YES Bank, Tata Steel below 200-DMAsYES Bank, Tata Steel, HDFC Life, DLF, NMDC, BPCL, Reliance Nippon, Ashoka Buildcon, L&T Finance and Cummins India were among the stocks that witnessed negative breakouts and traded below their 200-DMAs. On the other hand, Mastek, FCS Software and Gujarat Heavy Chemicals were among the stocks that traded above their 200-DMAs.


179 stocks signal potential fallMomentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD, showed bearish crossovers on 179 counters on BSE, signalling imminent fall in these stocks. Among them were DHFL, IDBI Bank, BHEL, Tata Steel, Wockhardt and Omaxe. Meanwhile, 47 stocks, including L&T Infotech, Britannia Industries, Timex Group India and Alicon Castalloy, witnessed bullish crossovers.


RIL shares fall 3%Shares of Reliance Industries (RIL) fell 2.76 per cent to Rs 1,344.80 even after the company on Thursday reported March quarter profit in line with estimates. Some market participants said while the better-than-expected March quarter profit numbers were already in the price, lower average revenue per user (Arpu) of RIL’s telecom business Jio disappointed investors.


HDFC Bank slips despite good Q4 showShares of HDFC Bank closed 0.96 per cent lower at Rs 2,268, falling prey to a broader selloff as most bank stocks bled. The fall was capped as brokerages gave a thumbs up to the lender's March quarter numbers. The bank's Rs 5,885 crore quarterly profit was highest ever for any quarter and it marked the third straight quarter of Rs 5,000 crore-plus profit for the bank.


Jet shares fall 6%Shares of Jet Airways closed 5.67 per cent down at Rs 154.60, extending the losses into the third consecutive session. In last three sessions, the scrip has come off 41 per cent. After the closure of operations, the airline is now facing the risk of landing at NCLT as one of its service providers shot a notice under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code of 2016 to pay up its dues within 10 days.


DHFL shares crack 11%Shares of Dewan Housing Finance Corporation (DHFL) closed 10.91 per cent down at Rs 140.05 after rating agency Crisil downgraded the company's commercial papers worth Rs 850 crore from A2+ to A3+ and continued on watch negative. In a BSE filing, the company said Crisil's belief that liquidity levels remain subdued and low visibility in raising funds were the reasons for downgrading the stock.


SpiceJet breaks 5-day winning streakShares of SpiceJet cracked as much as 8.15 per cent to Rs 125.15 after five consecutive days of gains. In the last five sessions, the stock had jumped 44 per cent. A surge in crude oil prices is seen as a reason for the fall in the stock price.


Oil & gas top sectoral loserThe BSE oil & gas index settled 3.20 per cent lower at 14,528.31, leading the pack of sectoral losers. All components of the index suffered losses in the light of a sharp rise in global crude oil prices.

SWAPNEEL V MANTRI TECHNICAL ANALYST – INSTITUTIONS, SUSHIL FINANCE

Britannia, HUL, Hero Motocorp, Apollo Tyres, Balkrishna Ind and GSK Consumers are some of the stocks that look promising on the charts, they said.

What is in store: Expect rangebound trade on the Nifty as we head into the expiry week. Levels wise, 11,820-11,890 target zones and 11,600-11,720 support zones. Nifty’s 200 DMA is at 10,980.


What could investors do: Investors can look at accumulating quality scrips from a long term point of view. NEW DELHI: It took just two sessions for Nifty50 to test the sub-10,600 level on Monday from an all-time high of 11,856 hit last Thursday. Friday was a public holiday.

While trading kicked off on a positive note on Tuesday, back-to-back selloffs seen in the previous two sessions made analysts believe the breakout signal triggered by the reclamation of the previous peak of 11,761 was probably false. If that’s so, outlook for over a hundred stocks would look weak, as suggested by various technical indicators.

Among them one is the momentum indicator moving average convergence divergence, or MACD charts, which is already signalling a bearish bias for 127 stocks on NSE.

The indicator showed bearish crossovers – a negative undertone – on these counters, hinting at possible downsides in the days ahead. 

Many of these stocks have also been witnessing strong trading volumes of late, lending credence to the emerging trend.

The stocks on the list are from across sectors like financials, drug makers and consumers as well as firms due to unveil their earnings. 

The list included Suzlon Energy, Dewan Housing (DHFL), Reliance Infrastructure, BHEL, IDBI Bank, Tata Steel, Wockhardt, Strides Pharma, Future Consumer and JK Paper, among others.

Marksans Pharma, Dhanlakshmi Bank, J&K Bank, Tata Chemicals, SBI Life Insurance, CEAT, Dr Reddy’s Labs, JSW Energy, CESC and The Ramco Cement, too, are a part of the list.











Tata Global Beverages and ACC, which are scheduled to announce their quarterly numbers later on Tuesday, too, are part of this list. 

The MACD is known for signalling trend reversals in traded securities or indices. It is the difference between the 26-day and 12-day exponential moving averages. A nine-day exponential moving average, called the signal line, is plotted on top of the MACD to reflect ‘buy’ or ‘sell’ opportunities.

When the MACD crosses above the signal line, it gives a bullish signal, indicating that the price of the security may see an upward movement and vice versa. 

Data showed 18 stocks made bullish crossovers on Monday. The list included Gati, Quick Heal Technologies, Britannia Industries, L&T Infotech and Monsanto India.





The MACD indicator should not be seen in isolation, as it may not be sufficient to take a trading call, just the way a fundamental analyst cannot give a ‘buy’ or ‘sell’ recommendation using a single valuation ratio. 

Traders should make use of other indicators such as Relative Strength Index (RSI), Bollinger Bands, Fibonacci Series, candlestick patterns and Stochastic to confirm an emerging trend. 

“At this juncture, the ideal strategy would be to stay light on positions. It’s better not to pre-empt any kind of moves. Instead, one should try to adopt a confirmatory approach for a while,” said Sameet Chavan of Angel Broking.

He expects Nifty50 to find resistance at 11,653 and then 11,705 levels.

Gaurav Ratnaparkhi of Sharekhan believes the swing low of 11,550 holds the key for further move. “A breach of this level on a closing basis shall entail a deeper correction in Nifty50,” he said.


Understanding MACD
 
A close look at the stock chart of Suzlon Energy shows whenever the MACD line has breached below the signal line, the stock has shown a downward momentum and vice versa. On Tuesday, the scrip traded 2.90 per cent lower at Rs 6.60 on NSE.

When it comes to investing in Indian stocks, consumption is a theme one can ill-afford to ignore.

While rising incomes and an ever-growing younger population make consumption a sure-shot bet, newer trends in the market are throwing up definitive cues on where money is waiting to be made.

Indian policymakers’ increased focus on financially empowering the poor, and rapid spread of mobile and internet are working as an icing on the cake for investors looking to cash in on India’s consumption boom.

India Inc is taking note.

Billionaire businessman Mukesh Ambani last month acquired ITC’s mid-segment menswear brand John Players to strengthen Reliance Retail’s readymade garments and accessories portfolio in the fashion and lifestyle retail space.

In another development, Aditya Birla-led Grasim Industries acquired Soktas India for Rs 135.12 crore. Soktas India is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Soktas Tekstil Sanayi ve Ticaret AS, a world-renowned producer and marketer of premium shirting fabrics with its main facilities at Soke in Turkey.

The growth potential of India’s consumption sector can also be gauged from the fact that India emerged as the only big market to clock FMCG growth of 13.8 per cent in 2018 while global growth stood at 2-2.50 per cent, according to AC Nielson.

That high base may result in a slowdown in consumption this year, but it still remains a solid bet for faster growth.

“This sector is in a long-term bull market,” says Atul Suri, CEO, Marathon Trends PMS. “I have been overweight on consumption on a longer timeframe,” he told ETNow in an interview.

Divergent trends have emerged in this space of late; some stocks are faltering while others are touching lifetime highs. 

“There are divergent trends emerging across the sector. We like to identify stocks and watch their behaviour in a falling market, because stocks that go up or hold up well in a falling market usually emerge as leaders in the next bull market,” Suri said.

Analysts say lifestyle changes among individuals, especially millennials, is the hottest theme, as this is what is increasingly driving India’s consumption story.

There are expectations that India will become the largest country globally in terms of population size at 1.60 billion by 2030. It currently has around 1.05 billion citizens in the age group of 15-60 against China’s 0.98 billion.

Going with market experts, FMCG, e-commerce, smartphone manufacturers, auto, telecom, education, and services are some of the industries that are likely to benefit, given the spending behaviour of these consumers. 

In the offline space, the salience of food products is increasing in every retail outlet as witnessed in rising throughput per store, says Elara Capital.

The brokerage believes the food space is expected to perform better than home and personal care (HPC) products in calendar 2019. 

Elara recommends Britannia with a price target of Rs 3,478 and Nestle with a target price of Rs 11,716 as these companies have been growing direct reach every year.

In the online space, health (juices), organic, babycare products (diapers, skincare and wipes), ready-to-eat and ready-to-cook products and children & school-oriented foods were among the fastest-growing categories in Calendar 2018. 
At present, eCommerce contributes around 2 per cent of total FMCG sales in India. With the rise of smartphone us, the figure is likely to multiply in the days ahead.

India is projected to have around 1,200 million smartphone users by 2030 against 300 million in 2016. It may touch 440 million by the end of next year, according to a research done by AC Nielsen and Elara Securities.

Select companies are already doing profitable business riding the eCommerce boom.

Bata India’s Ram Kumar Gupta says its eCommerce business is quite profitable and the contribution from the medium is almost 6 per cent. 

Brokerage Nirmal Bang Securities has an ‘accumulate’ rating on Bata India with a target price of Rs 1,479.

Organised players engaged in production and distribution of health food drinks as well as milk and milk products are the others to watch.

India’s per capita milk consumption stood at 110 gm until 1970s and was declining. It now stands at 370-380 gm and is expected to reach 800-850 gm a day (equivalent to that of Europe and the US today) by 2030. In the dairy space, Elara is bullish on Heritage Foods and Parag Milk Foods with price targets of Rs 825 and Rs 366, respectively.

Despite a 12.50 per cent rally, the BSE FMCG index underperformed Sensex (up 15 per cent) in FY19. Stocks like Balrampur Chini Mills, Dalmia Bharat, United Breweries, Godfrey Phillips, Dabur, Nestle, HUL and Britannia Industries advanced 25-77 per cent during the financial year, while Kwality, Manpasand Beverages, LT Foods and Ruchi Soya tanked over 50 per cent.

The growth baton has shifted from global cyclicals to the domestic cyclicals and domestic cyclicals is nothing but banks, said Gautam Duggad, Head - Research, Institutional Equities, Motilal Oswal Financial Services, in an interview with ETNOW. Edited excerpts:


Will the outperformance this earnings season remain with the financials or do you think there is a fair chance that there could be some other dark horses too?
Absolutely. This is a quarter of financials. We are expecting a 15% Nifty earnings growth but you take out the three corporate banks and the growth is a decline of 3% for the Nifty. 

For our broader universe under Motilal Oswal coverage, we are expecting a 29% growth but again if you take out PSU banks where we are seeing a swing from a loss of Rs 24,000 crore odd in the base quarter to a profit of Rs 5,000-crore odd, the growth is absolutely flat. So this is a quarter of financials. Last quarter was also the same. 

In the third quarter FY19 also, the Nifty earnings growth was somewhere around 8-9% and ex of those three banks, the growth is 0%. So clearly, FY20 is going to be led by financials. For whatever reason, if there are big changes in the financials’ numbers -- either on the upside or on the downside -- it will have a disproportionate impact on the broader market earnings. 

It is a very crucial part of FY20 earnings recovery because ex of those banks, Nifty earnings growth for FY20 is just 13-14% which in itself is a very healthy number if you compare with the trend in the last four or five years, but the expected reported growth of 24% is by and large been driven by the corporate banks which is where our portfolio is overweight.


You are looking at PSUs closely. What you are anticipating there and why do you feel that earnings growth could be led by that pocket?
As far as PSUs are concerned, we just have SBI in our portfolio where we have actually increased the weightage by 100 bps this quarter. Other than SBI, rest of the PSU banks are going to see extreme volatility, specifically pertaining to the quarter you are sitting on. For one, the base will be extremely benign. In the base quarter, SBI had reported a Rs 7,000-8,000-crore loss, PNB had reported Rs 13,000 crore of loss and BOB had also reported a loss of Rs 3,000 crore. So, in Q4 this year, our estimate is around Rs 5,000 crore of profit amongst these three, four banks which is sequentially flat, but the year-on-year comparison looks very good. 

Going forward, we will still have to be very watchful on the asset quality trends plus the capitalisation levels and how the growth on the credit side that we are getting because the fact remains that post the NBFC crisis in September, we have seen market share shifting away from NBFCs to the banks and the early results which have come in from the private banks side -- be it HDFC Bank of DCB, AU, RBL. The numbers were very fantastic for all the four banks -- be it credit quality, top line growth or margins. Clearly, the market share shift from NBFC incrementally towards the banks is underway. 

The early beneficiary obviously will be the private banks given the capitalisation levels which are there and overall liquidity situation in the market. From a PSU bank point of view, we are clearly more biased towards SBI. 

From a trade perspective, last quarter we had added PNB which still remains a part of the portfolio but that was more a valuation call. As far as fundamental, structural earnings trajectory is concerned, one will have to see how the overall asset quality trends pans out for the next two or three quarters because incrementally new issues keep coming to the fore. 


Which are the sectors you would avoid? 
In FY17-18 and a large part of FY19, the earnings growth was by and large led by two metals and oil and gas. Incrementally, since the second quarter of FY19, the growth baton has shifted from global cyclicals to the domestic cyclicals and domestic cyclicals is nothing but banks which we discussed a minute back. 

As far as global cyclicals are concerned, in the second half of FY19, the earnings trajectory of metals started moderating and in FY20, we will get the first year of earnings decline vis-à-vis the performance of last three years. 

Similarly, for oil and gas, for the quarter we are expecting a very flat growth, largely because of the decline that we are expecting in OMCs. Last quarter, OMCs had completely gone down the drain with a 90% YoY profit decline. This quarter, while YoY comparison looks sequentially slightly better, at a 25-30% decline, it is still a meaningful decline.

The other stocks where we are seeing growth are Reliance or ONGC. But there the valuations remain crippled because of the various policy related issues as far as the upstream oil companies are concerned and now with crude at $74-75, there is always a cap on the valuation expansion that one can expect. So they remain a value pack. Their PE ratios are not very expensive but that is the band that they have traded in the past and incrementally the earnings trajectory is moderating. That is where we have been underweight for some time now.

Pharma is a sector which has not seen any earnings growth for last four-five years. While a few companies may have done well here and there in that broader pack of 25 stocks that we cover will have good quarter especially the midcaps. But for largecaps, the earnings fortune remains very subdued even on a low base. 

Five years back, the earnings pool for our pharma universe was at around Rs 17,000-18,000 crore. After five years, it is at Rs 21,000 crore. We have had hardly seen any growth and incrementally the return ratios for these companies in the pharma sector have been in the 14-15% band. So while their call is defensive, but the return ratios are not defensives. Earning predictability is not there and at the margin, we are not seeing any meaningful improvement. While the decline has stemmed, you are not seeing any catalyst for an upside right now. 


Your top picks include Titan, Pidilite. Also some of the banks have had a really good run of late. What you would do with some of these names?
Some of these names have done exceedingly well. When you look at consumption companies -- Titan, Pidilite, Hindustan Lever or Britannia -- you cannot take a view on them from a one-year perspective because these are very solid franchises with underlying trends in their favour. 

For example, Titan is the biggest beneficiary of unorganised to organised move following GST. We have been liking the stock since 2016. It was expensive even then, it is more expensive today. But the fact remains that in the Rs 2 lakh-crore jewellery market, the composition of the organised trade is still sub-20%. 

So, the growth horizon for companies like Titan is a multi-year growth story. So, do you want to take a one-year forward PE call and sell it today and then regret later? It is obviously a “no”. But these stocks can have a substantial period of time correction -- be it 6, 12 months -- nobody knows. 

But the strategy on such long-term structural story is to buy and hold. Pidilite has always looked expensive at any given point of time in the last five years. The stock has still compounded pretty well. Same is the case with Hindustan Lever also, Britannia. I recognised that the valuations are expensive on one year forward basis. These stocks could have a time correction and if monsoon is not favourable, maybe there could be a decline. 

But timing the stock is something very difficult in the consumption space. We will have our four or five preferred bets and that we will keep on holding. That is the call on consumption and on private banks. We still see that the new cycle has just begun and there is a possibility of earnings upgrade happening in the next one or two years for a lot of these well managed private corporate banks. 

In fact, in the last quarter, we had seen earnings upgrade for ICICI and Axis after a long time. We have not seen any earnings change in these banks and incrementally the credit quality is improving, the guidance for our ROE is far stronger. We have seen the results of some of the midcap private sector banks also. Right now the cycle has just begun. While they have done well, in a new upcycle, valuations do tend to overshoot just like in a down cycle. We have seen valuations undershoot for a fairly long period of time in 2016, 17 and 18. We will remain biased towards private corporate banks at this stage. 

Within the retail space in the private banks, our preference still remains with HDFC Bank. That is how we are positioned on consumption and private banks.
